The  Project  consists  of 
in 
Alashankou land port, Kanas scenic region, and Yining City, which 
are  all  located  in  northern  or  northwestern  Xinjiang  Uygur 
Autonomous Region (Xinjiang), bordering with countries in Central 
Asia.  The  Project  aims  to  strengthen  cross-border  trade,  tourism 
development,  and  economic  growth  in  order  to  raise  living 
standards  while  protecting  the  environment  of  the  people  living 
and  working  in  one  of  the  poorest  and  most  remote  parts  of  the 
country.  The  Yining  component  aims  to  (i)  improve  the  existing 
road infrastructure in order to assist commercial access to cross-
border trade and improve urban living conditions; and (ii) expand 
roads  and utility  services  into  new development  areas  to  support 
industrial  activity,  improve  the  local  economy,  and  increase 
employment.  The  Alashankou  component  will  develop  new 
infrastructure and upgrade existing infrastructure services in order 
to improve living conditions, encourage expansion of cross-border 
trade,  expand  the  local  economy,  and  reduce  pollution.  The 
Kanas component will provide new water supply, sanitation, solid 
waste  management,  and  road  network  infrastructure  in  order  to 
develop  tourism  and  the  local  economy,  improve  the  living 
conditions  and  health  of  ethnic  minorities,  and  protect  the 
environment.  The  area  includes  a  nationally  designated  tourist 
destination. 
 
The Project is the first ADB-financed municipal infrastructure and 
environmental  management  project 
to  support 
environmentally  sustainable  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction  and  facilitate  regional  trade  between  the  PRC  and  the 
Central  Asian  republics  (CARs).  Xinjiang  shares  borders  with 
eight  countries  and  is  the  gateway  between  the  PRC  and  the 
CARs. As the historic Silk Road passes through it, Xinjiang has a 
wealth  of  history  and  ethnic  culture,  and  this  has  encouraged 
in  natural 
tourism  development.  The

resources—including  oil,  metals,  and  minerals—that  provide  a 
sound  basis  for  economic  development.  Although  Xinjiang’s 
foreign trade has grown rapidly since 1992, the province remains 
one  of  the  poorest  in  the  country.  To  maximize  growth  potential 
and raise the living standard of the people (particularly that of the 
ethnic  minorities), 
the  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region 
government  (XUARG)  in  its  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  accorded 
high  priority 
through 
construction  and  upgrade  of  infrastructure,  particularly  in  major 
border ports and cities.  
 
Given  Xinjiang’s  location  and  abundance  in  resources,  XUARG 
focuses  its  development  strategy  on  the  province’s  potential  role 
in  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC) 
Program.  ADB  has  supported 
trade 
facilitation,  customs  cooperation  and  modernization,  and 
infrastructure development through the CAREC Program since the 
late  1990s.  This  Project,  and  the  recently  approved  Xinjiang 
Regional  Road  Development  Project  (Korla–Kuqa  Section)  and 
the  Xinjiang  Urban  Transport  and  Environmental  Improvement 
Project that is currently under preparation, fully support XUARG’s 
development  objectives,  the  CAREC  program,  and  the  CAREC 
Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy (which is currently being 
prepared). Improvement of the road network and accessibility and 
strengthening  of  environmental  protection  and  management  is 
crucial  to  achieving  and  sustaining  inclusive  growth  in  Xinjiang’s 
border  cities  and  areas.  An  efficient,  safe,  and  environmentally 
sustainable road transport network, together with improved public 
utility and environmental infrastructure, is needed (i) to cope with 
the  increasing  demand  resulting  from  cross-border  trade  growth, 
tourism  development,  industrial  development,  and  urbanization; 
and  (ii)  to  benefit  the  poor  and  ethnic  minorities.  Policy  and 
institutional  reforms  in  transport  planning,  traffic  management, 
infrastructure  operations  and  maintenance,  and  environmental 
management  have  been  taken  into  consideration  in  the  project 
design. 
 
The  Project  aims  to  remove  infrastructure  constraints,  address 
environmental  concerns,  and  promote  sustainable  economic 
growth  in  three  of  Xinjiang’s  border  cities  and  areas  and  is 
consistent  with  the  PRC’s  development  priorities  for  the  poor 
western  region.  The  Project  covers  a  range  of  settlements—a 
medium-sized  city,  a  small  but  rapidly  expanding  land  port,  and 
four  villages  in  a  fast-growing  tourist  attraction  area—which  will 
have  a  demonstration  role  for  other  similar  cities  and  areas  on 
how  to  plan  and  manage  sustainable  infrastructure  development 
before rapid economic growth occurs in order to ensure protection 
of 
the  environment.  The  Project  supports  ADB’s  country 
partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC,  which  aims  to  strengthen 
inclusiveness,  manage 
regional 
cooperation  and  integration,  catalyze  investment,  and  improve 
governance, and it also supports ADB’s CAREC strategy. It is also 
consistent  with  ADB’s  urban  sector  strategy  and  water  policy, 
which  support  infrastructure  investment  in  settlements  that  are

The impact of the Project is sustained socioeconomic growth and 
improved living standards in the border areas of northern Xinjiang 
(Altay  Administrative  District,  Boertala  Mongolian  Autonomous 
Prefecture, and Yili Kazak Autonomous Prefecture). The outcome 
is  improved  municipal  infrastructure  and  a  better  living  and 
ecological  environment  in  Alashankou  land  port,  Kanas  scenic 
region, and Yining City. 
 
The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $190.9 million, 
including taxes and duties of $25.2 million.

Xinjiang  is  a  low-income  region,  especially  when  compared  with 
the coastal provinces. Within Xinjiang, Yining (home to 93% of all 
project beneficiaries) is a low-income area with a mean per capita 
income  less  than  half  that  of  the  Xinjiang  urban  average.  The 
Project will benefit about 471,400 people, 10% of whom are poor. 
Major  socioeconomic  impacts  include  (i)  improvement  of  living 
standards  through  the  provision  of  essential  public  infrastructure, 
(ii) improvement  of  public  health 
infrastructure  and 
environmental  improvement,  (iii)  improvement  of  the  quality  and 
affordability of basic services, and (iv) significant job creation.  
 
About  24%  of  the  beneficiaries  in  Alashankou  will  be  ethnic 
minorities;  in  Kanas  the  figure  is  97%,  and  in  Yining  82%.  All 
households will be able to afford ongoing utility bills for the new or 
extended  services

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Xinjiang Municipal Infrastructure and Environmental 
Improvement Project. 
 
2. 
The  Government  asked  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  help  improve  municipal 
infrastructure and the environment in Alashankou land port, Kanas scenic region, and Yining City 
in  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region  (Xinjiang)  by  (i)  improving  the  existing  road  infrastructure 
and expanding roads and utility services into new development areas of Yining; (ii) developing new 
and  upgrading  existing  infrastructure  services  in  Alashankou;  and  (iii)  providing  water  supply, 
sanitation, solid waste management, and road network infrastructure in Kanas. This report is based 
on  the  results  of  the  loan  appraisal  mission,  as  well  as  discussions  with  the  central  and  local 
governments and community organizations. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1. The problems and objectives tree analyses are in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

3. 
The PRC has experienced significant economic progress since the Government initiated a 
series of economic and social reforms in 1978. Rapid industrialization and urbanization have seen 
the economy grow faster than in most other parts in the world, averaging more than 9% annually 
since  1978 and  over  10%  annually  during  the  period  2001–2006.  Policies  to  open  the  country  to 
international trade and investment have made the PRC one of the world's most open economies. 
Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  in  2006  was  CNY20,940  billion  ($2,785  billion),  compared  with 
CNY362.4  billion  ($48.2  billion)  in  1978.  Per  capita  GDP  in  2006  was  CNY15,930  ($2,118).  The 
country has reached the Millennium Development Goal of cutting the 1990 poverty rate by half and 
is  on  track  to  reach  most  of  the  other  Millennium  Development  Goals.1 However,  the  western 
region  of  the  PRC,  which  is  home  to  many  of  the  country’s  poor  and  ethnic  minorities,  has  not 
benefited as much as the coastal regions from rapid economic growth and reforms.2 The western 
region  accounts  for  71.5%  of  the  country’s  total  area  and  contains  more  than  half  of  its  natural 
resources  but  has  only  27.5%  of  the  country’s  population  and  18.8%  of  the  country’s  total 
economic output as of 2006. About 50.8% of the 23.65  million poor people in the PRC live in this 
region. 
 
4. 
In  1999,  the  Government  launched  the  western  region  development  strategy,  aimed  at 
promoting  balanced  economic  growth,  stimulating  economic  development,  and  raising  the  living 
standard of the population in the western region. While growth has quickened recently, the western 
region still lags behind the coastal region. In 2005, the GDP per capita of the western region was 
only 60% of the national average, and disposable income per capita was only 84% of the national 
average. The provision of roads and municipal infrastructure and services has not kept pace with 
increasing  demand,  and  this  hinders  outside  investment,  contributes  to  poor  environmental 
conditions, and limits opportunities to promote growth. 
 
5. 
Despite massive investments in road infrastructure, the inadequate transportation and road 
network  still  constitutes  a  major  obstacle  to  production  and  consumption  activities,  domestic  and

Development Goals. Beijing. By 2006, the number of poor people below the government's poverty line had fallen by 
about 230 million to 21.5 million, or 2.3% of the rural population, and the number living on less than $1 per day had 
fallen by about 350 million to around 105 million, or about 10% of the rural population. 

2   The PRC’s  western region covers six provinces, five autonomous regions (including the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous 

Region), and one municipality (Chongqing). 

 2 

 

international trade, and sustainable economic growth in the western region. In 2005, the total road 
network  in  the  PRC  reached  1.93  million  kilometers  (km),  of  which  0.78  million  km  were  in  the 
western region. Given increased incomes and prosperity and reduced tariffs on vehicles following 
the PRC’s accession to the World Trade Organization, car ownership, which reached 21 vehicles 
per 1,000 people nationwide in 2005, is likely to continue its rapid increase. Rapid growth in vehicle 
numbers  and  passenger  transport  has  put  increasing  pressure  on  the  road  network,  which 
necessitates capacity expansion, transport planning, and improved road and traffic management. 
These  are  all  major  areas  of  the  Government’s  policy  to  ensure  sustainable  development  while 
protecting the environment. 
 
6. 
Rapid urbanization and industrialization in the PRC have come at a high environmental cost. 
The PRC’s urban population has more than tripled from 190 million in 1980 to 577 million in 2006, 
accounting  for  43.9%  of  the  national  population,  and  is  expected  to  reach  47.0%  by  2010.  Many 
cities  face  environmental  threats  from  pollution  of  surface  and  subsurface  waters  from  untreated 
wastewater and solid waste. As of 2006, about 56% of urban wastewater was treated and the rest 
was  discharged  untreated. 3  The  Government’s  latest  agenda  for  economic  reform  and  social 
development aims to (i) accelerate urbanization and the development of large, medium, and small 
cities and towns; and (ii) protect the environment by reducing air pollution by 20% and increasing 
wastewater  treatment  coverage  to  70%  by  2010.  The  growing  urban  population,  industrialization, 
and  economic  development  will  continue  to  increase  the  demand  for  infrastructure  services, 
including  roads,  water  supply,  wastewater,  and  sanitation,  which  will  severely  strain  the  physical 
and financial capacity of most cities, particularly those in the western region. In the PRC’s Eleventh

7. 
Project  Background.  The  western  region  development  policy  continues  to  be  a  major 
thrust  of  the  Government’s  11FYP.  The  main  focus  is  on  (i)  improving  border  port  facilities,  (ii) 
strengthening  economic  cooperation  and  trade  with  neighboring  countries,  (iii)  improving 
the  environment  and  encouraging  private 
infrastructure  development,  and  (iv)  protecting 
investment.  ADB 
initiative  and  has 
recommended that, among other things, the western region development strategy should focus on 
accelerating  infrastructure  development  (transportation,  communications,  power,  and  water 
resources) and environmental management to lay a foundation for development.4  
 
8. 
Xinjiang covers 1.665 million square kilometers, about one sixth of the total area of the PRC 
and is the largest of its provinces and autonomous regions. It has a relatively small population of 
about  20  million  (about  1.5%  of  the  population  of  the  PRC),  of  whom  about  38.0%  are  Han 
Chinese  and  the  rest  are  from  46  ethnic  minority  groups,  the  largest  of  which  is  the  Uygur, 
accounting for 47.0%. Xinjiang shares 5,600 km of border with eight countries and is the gateway 
between  the  PRC  and  the  Central  Asian  republics  (CARs), 5  with  which  it  has  many  cultural

the Asian and Pacific Region, 28–29 August 2007, Beijing. 

4  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Provincial Development Strategy of Selected

during the period 2007–2009, more than 90% of which will be allocated to the central and western regions, with the top 
three priorities being transport, municipal infrastructure, and environmental protection.  

5  Xinjiang  shares  borders  with  Afghanistan,  India,  Kazakhstan,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Mongolia,  Pakistan,  the  Russian 
Federation, and Tajikistan. The Second Eurasia Continental Bridge railway line connects Rotterdam in western Europe 
to Lianyungang in East Asia, via Alashankou in Xinjiang. 

  

 

3 

similarities and economic complementarities. As the historic Silk Road passes through it, Xinjiang 
has a wealth of history and ethnic culture, and this has encouraged tourism development. It is also 
rich in natural resources including oil, metals, minerals, and products with low factor costs for labor 
and  land,  which  provide  a  sound  basis  for  development.  While  economic  development  has  been 
rapid (with an annual growth rate of 9.8% in the last 5 years), Xinjiang remains one of the poorest 
and  most  remote  parts  of  the  country.  Of  its  22  cities  and  68  counties,  27  are  categorized  as 
national poverty cities or counties. In 2006, about 8.4% of Xinjiang’s urban population had incomes 
below the official poverty line; this compares with the national average poverty incidence of 4.0%. 
For  the  rural  population  the  figure  in  2006  was  10.0%,  compared  with  the  national  average  of 
3.2%. 6 In  2005,  Xinjiang’s  per  capita  disposable  income  of  urban  households  was  CNY7,990 
($1,044),  the  lowest  among  the  PRC’s  autonomous  regions  and  provinces,  24.0%  below  the 
national average, and 57.0% below that of Shanghai. The main factors which limit the economy are 
(i) the vast distances that separate Xinjiang from major markets, and (ii) inadequate and outdated 
infrastructure  facilities—especially  roads,  water  supply,  and  sanitation—that  cannot  satisfy  the 
present demand and support potential growth. 
 
9. 
The urban population in Xinjiang, which accounted for 37% of the total population in 2005, 
is  expected  to  increase  to  42%  by  2010  and  to  47%  by  2015.  Between  1995  and  2005,  paved 
roads in urban areas in Xinjiang increased 60%, from 2,403 km to 3,849 km. This can barely cope 
with  the  growth  in  vehicle  and  passenger  transport.  In  the  same  period,  the  number  of  public 
vehicles  for  business  transportation  increased  by  127%,  from  3,324  to  7,553,  and  the  number  of 
passenger  trips  increased  by  41%,  from  1.831  million  to  2.583  million  person-times  per  day. 
Vehicle  ownership  reached  33  vehicles  per  1,000  people.  Other  environment  infrastructure 
services  are  also  facing  problems  associated  with  growing  demand.  In  2005,  634  million  cubic 
meters  of  wastewater  were  discharged,  68%  of  which  comes  from  municipal  sources  and  32% 
from industrial sources. Of these discharges, 59.3% of the industrial wastewater met the discharge 
standards,  and  55.3%  of  the  municipal  wastewater  was  treated,  while  the  balance  either  did  not 
meet established standards or was untreated. In 2005, 3.44 million tons of garbage were collected 
and  disposed  of;  36%  of  this  waste  was  treated  in  nine  sanitary  landfill  sites. 7  Significant 
investments  are  needed  to  expand  the  infrastructure  facilities  and  improve  environmental 
management  to  ensure  sustainable  economic  growth  and  raise  the  living  standards  of  the  poor 
people in Xinjiang, particularly those in the border areas. 
 
10. 
The  Project  covers  three  border  cities  and  areas—Alashankou  land  port,  Kanas  scenic 
region,  and  Yining  City—which  are  fast-growing  economic  and  tourism  hubs  in  the  northwestern 
part of Xinjiang. The present transport infrastructure and services cannot meet the increasing traffic 
and  utility  service  demands  in  these  areas.  The  incomplete  road  networks,  low  standard  of 
transport infrastructure, and poor management and maintenance, all contribute to increasing traffic 
congestion and accidents. Utility services do not exist or are old, fragile, and inadequate, resulting 
in  poor  standards  and  frequent  failure  of  services.  The  investment  needs  far  exceed  the  budget 
allocations of the local governments on capital investment and operation and maintenance (O&M) 
of these services. 
 
11. 
Income  from  tourism  in  the  PRC  is  expected  to  grow  by  12%  per  annum  in  the  11FYP 
period. In Xinjiang, from 2000 to 2005, the annual number of tourists increased from 7.8 million to 
15.0 million, and the earnings from tourism increased from $0.9 billion to $1.8 billion. The growth in 
tourism in Xinjiang has contributed to economic development in its poorer areas. For example, in

person per day.

$0.11  billion,  14%  of  the  gross  regional  product  of  $0.76  billion.  There  will  be  barriers  to  further

12. 
The  Alashankou  land  port,  established  in  1995,  has  a  population  of  29,000.  It  is  the  only 
land  port  in  the  western  region  with  cross-border  road  and  rail  links  as  well  as  pipelines  for 
petroleum  products.  Its  link  with  Dostyk  in  Kazakhstan  is  part  of  the  Second  Eurasia  Continental 
Bridge railway line and the major trade route carrying materials and products between Xinjiang and 
industrial and agricultural consumers and producers both within and outside of the PRC. In 2005, 
its total imports and exports reached $6.8 billion, the largest in Xinjiang (comprising over 90% of 
the total for Xinjiang) and second largest in the PRC. Major export items are manufactured goods 
such as shoes and TV sets, while major import items are natural resources such as crude oil and 
rolled steel. The PRC signed a cross-border transportation agreement with Kazakhstan in 2005 to 
facilitate cross-border trade. Import and export activities at the land port are increasing at 25% per 
year.  To  ensure  the  land  port’s  sustainable  growth,  and  in  order  to  overcome  major  trade 
facilitation  and  development  constraints  due  to  inadequate  infrastructure,  the  Project  will  include 
construction and upgrading of roads, water supply, and heating infrastructure and the provision of 
new wastewater and solid waste treatment and management facilities. It will also include planting 
and irrigation of forests for ecological protection in a very harsh, dry, and windy semidesert climate. 
This will also improve the economy of nearby border areas, which are generally underdeveloped, 
by benefiting the processing, tertiary, and agricultural sectors. 
 
13. 
The Kanas scenic region is in the northern tip of Xinjiang, which borders Kazakhstan, the 
Russian  Federation,  and  Mongolia.  It  is  a  nationally  designated  top-ranking  tourist  destination, 
covers seven villages, and has a total population of about 4,400. Roads in the villages are in poor 
condition and inaccessible for at least 7 months of the year, essentially isolating the residents. The 
recent  rapid  increase  in  tourist  numbers  has  led  to  rapid  development  of  the  region.  Wastewater 
and refuse have polluted some of the pastures, rivers, and lakes. The project component, located 
in  four  villages,  is  needed  in  order  to  (i)  improve  the  infrastructure  and  services  to  meet  the 
residents’ basic needs and accessibility within the villages, and (ii) support sustainable economic 
growth  and  poverty  reduction  in  Kanas  through  tourism  development  while  ensuring  proper 
management  and  protection  of  the  environment.8 International  tourism  experts  estimate  that  the 
multiplier  effect  of  the  tourism  industry  in  developing  countries  with  abundant  tourism  resources 
results in a ratio of indirect to direct economic benefits of about 4:3. 
 
14. 
Yining City, with a population of 438,000, is located in the northwest of Xinjiang and is an 
important trade hub between the PRC and Central Asia. Upgrading of the road network is needed 
to  support  growth.  Traffic  management  and  road  safety  measures—such  as  the  segregation  of 
pedestrians  and  vehicles—need  to  be  improved.  The  Project  includes  the  construction  and 
upgrading  of  both  arterial  roads  and  urban  alleys  to  serve  the  needs  of  residents,  improve  air 
quality,  and  reduce  accident  rates.  It  will  also  provide  associated  infrastructure  including  water 
supply,  wastewater  treatment,  heating,  telecommunications,  and  other  municipal  services  under 
the roads. 
 
15. 
Project  Rationale.  Given  Xinjiang’s  location  and  abundance  in  resources,  the  Xinjiang 
Uygur Autonomous Region government (XUARG) focuses its development strategy on its potential 
role  in  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program.  ADB  has  been 
supporting  regional  trade  facilitation  through  the  CAREC  Program  since  the  late  1990s. 9 
Assistance  has  focused  on  regional  customs  cooperation,  customs  modernization,  trade

with trade and transport facilitation initiatives. 
 
16. 
Xinjiang’s foreign trade has grown rapidly, especially since the CARs became independent 
in 1992. It has increased more than fourfold (an annual average growth rate of 28.5%) from $1.77 
billion  in  2001  to  $7.94  billion  (exports  of  $5.04  billion  and  imports  of  $2.90  billion),  or  24.3%  of 
GDP,  in  2005,  the  highest  among  the  PRC’s  border  provinces  and  regions.  To  maximize  strong 
growth potential and raise the living standard of the people, in particular the ethnic minorities, the 
XUARG  in  its  11FYP  accorded  high  priority  to  sustainable  economic  development,  particularly  in 
border  cities  and  areas  with  tourism  potential,  through  construction  and  upgrading  of  the 
infrastructure,  while  at  the  same  time  protecting  the  environment.  This  Project,  and  the  recently 
approved  Xinjiang  Regional  Road  Development  Project  (Korla–Kuqa  Section)  and  the  Xinjiang 
Urban Transport and Environmental Improvement Project that is currently under preparation, fully 
support  XUARG’s  development  objectives  and  the  CAREC  transport  and  trade  facilitation 
strategy.10 
 
Improvement  of  the  road  network  and  the  strengthening  of  environmental  protection  and 
17. 
management is crucial to achieving and sustaining inclusive growth in Xinjiang’s border cities and 
areas.  An  efficient,  safe,  and  environmentally  sustainable  road  network,  together  with  improved 
public utility and environmental infrastructure, is needed to (i) cope with the increasing demand as 
a result of cross-border trade growth, industrial development, and urbanization; and (ii) benefit the 
poor  and  ethnic  minorities.  Road  and  environmental  infrastructure  is  also  urgently  needed  in  the 
Kanas villages, which are lacking these facilities. Institutional strengthening of transport planning, 
traffic management, municipal infrastructure, O&M, and environmental management is included in 
the project design. 
 
18. 
The  Project  is  designed  to  remove  infrastructure  constraints,  address  environmental 
concerns, and promote sustainable economic growth in three of Xinjiang’s border cities and areas, 
and is consistent with the PRC’s development priorities for the poor western region. The provision 
of improved or new infrastructure facilities in Alashankou land port will support the development of 
this small town into a larger land port with environmentally sustainable infrastructure services that 
will  facilitate  the  rapidly  growing  cross-border  trade  and  create  favorable  conditions  for  trade-
related  investment.  The  Project  will  also  support  tourism  development,  especially  in  Kanas  and 
Yining, to promote economic growth and reduce poverty, while protecting the environment. Thus it 
will have a demonstration effect for other similar border cities and land ports and areas with tourism 
potential on how to plan and manage sustainable infrastructure development, while protecting the 
environment. The Project supports ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, which aims to 
strengthen inclusiveness, manage the environment, promote regional cooperation and integration, 
catalyze  investment,  and  improve  governance,  and  also  supports  ADB’s  CAREC  strategy.  It  is 
consistent  with  ADB’s  urban  sector  strategy  and  water  policy,  which  support  infrastructure

Policy  Dialogue.  The  Project  will  build  on  ADB’s  policy  dialogue  on  (i) sustainable 
economic growth and environmental management; (ii) regional cooperation in trade facilitation; (iii)

20. 
To achieve long-term sustainable growth XUARG recognizes the need to balance economic 
development  and  social  and  environmental  concerns.  The  Project  will  introduce  measures  to 
prevent and control pollution through proper environmental planning and management and ensure 
environmentally  sustainable  economic  growth.  Most  of  Xinjiang suffers  from  water shortages  and 
overexploitation of surface water and groundwater, and the reuse of treated effluent would help to 
protect scarce water resources. The treated effluent should reach a discharge standard suitable for 
irrigation  or  industrial  cooling  and  heating.  This  has  been  incorporated  into  the  design  of  the 
Alashankou component. The Government of the PRC  is actively promoting a recycling economy, 
which  is  supported  under  the  Project  through  waste  sorting  and  recycling  in  order  to  minimize 
municipal solid waste and extend the operational life of landfills. The Project will include education 
programs  on  waste  recycling  and  provide  suitable  recycling  bins  and  facilities  for  residents  and 
tourists in Kanas. 
 
21. 
The  western  region  lacks  adequate  transport  infrastructure  and  trade  logistics  industries. 
Growth  of  trade  between  Xinjiang  and  the  CARs  is  promoting  economic  diversification  and 
assisting  enterprises,  but  a  major  obstacle  to  further  growth  is  the  high  cost  of  trade  across 
regions. In addition to improvement of the transport infrastructure, and in order to reduce transport 
time and costs along the CAREC trade transport corridors, CAREC partners will need to focus on 
priority 
improvement,  and  cross-border  harmonization.  The 
Alashankou  component  will  support  the  CAREC  program  and  the  transport  and  trade  facilitation 
strategy through improved road infrastructure which will strengthen cross-border trade in the border 
cities and areas of Xinjiang. 
 
22. 
Sustainable transport planning and policy reforms are crucial to ensure that the Project will 
bring added value and that the benefits will be passed on to road users. Urban transport planning 
must  take  into  account  the  links  between  land  use,  accessibility,  transport  services,  social  and 
poverty aspects, road accidents, road maintenance, and interagency cooperation. The master plan 
for each of the project cities and areas is being updated to meet the needs of a growing economy. 
XUARG  and  the  project  city  and  area  governments  recognize  that  integration  of  urban  planning 
and  transport  planning  is  important.  The  Project  will  assist  Yining  in  strengthening  its  capacity  to 
update and improve its urban development planning and transport master planning. 
 
Traffic management issues include (i) increased number and severity of road accidents, (ii) 
23. 
conflict between pedestrians and motorists, (iii) nonmotorized transport operations, and (iv) public 
transport  efficiency.  Road  safety  is  a  problem  in  the  PRC  and  insufficient  roads  and  inefficient 
traffic management are the main causes. Poor traffic management also has health, environmental, 
and  social  consequences,  and  significant  implications  for  national  economic  growth.  The  Project 
will introduce appropriate road safety strategies in the project cities and areas, including (i) traffic 
engineering  considerations  in  road  design  (focusing  on  existing  major  accident  areas),  (ii)  traffic 
management  (focusing  on  signage  and  appropriate  use  of  traffic  signal  controls),  (iii)  raising  of 
greater  community  and  industry  awareness  in  road  safety,  and  (iv)  dissemination  of  road  safety 
knowledge. Reduction in the frequency, severity, and cost of road accidents will particularly benefit 
low-income people—including pedestrians, public bus users, and bicycle riders—and increase the 
economic benefit of the investment. The Project will improve the road surfaces and introduce traffic 

transport  corridors,

and minimize pollution. 
 
24. 
ADB’s  municipal  infrastructure  projects  emphasize  the  importance  of  capacity  building  to 
increase  organizational  capability  to  ensure  that  (i)  the  project  components  are  designed  and 
constructed in a cost-effective manner and are implemented in compliance with environmental and 
social safeguards, (ii) O&M procedures are in place to enable the completed facilities to perform as 
designed,  (iii)  there  are  adequate  funding  mechanisms  for  effective  O&M  so  that  project  benefits 
can  be  sustained  in  the  long  term,  and  (iv)  there  is  overall  improvement  in  the  organizational 
performance  in  the  delivery  of  municipal  and  environmental  protection  services.  Institutional 
development is important for the Project because (i) Xinjiang and the project cities and areas have 
no  experience  in  ADB  projects,  and  (ii)  the  Project  involves  a  variety  of  works  in  dispersed 
locations  involving  many  levels  of  personnel.  The  institutional  development  measures  under  the 
Project  have  taken  these  factors  into  consideration.  During  preparation  of  the  Project,  ADB 
provided pre-project implementation training on ADB procedures and guidelines to XUARG and the 
implementing  agencies.  ADB  will  provide  further  capacity-building  measures  during  initial  project 
implementation.11 
 
25. 
ADB’s  infrastructure  projects  support  various  aspects  of  corporate  governance  reform, 
including (i) structuring the enterprises along commercial lines and assisting in preparing business 
plans where feasible, (ii) strengthening the operations of the boards of directors of the enterprises, 
and  accountability  through  supervisory  boards,  (iii)  implementing  external  and  internal  audit 
arrangements,  and  (iv)  improving  cost  recovery  through  tariff  reforms.  ADB  has  undertaken

sustainability  for  the  agencies  and  utilities  providing  municipal  services.  XUARG  has  agreed  to 
strengthen  tariff  reforms,  and  the  Project  will  provide  the  necessary  support  through  capacity 
development.  XUARG  has  agreed  to  use  accounting  systems  that  accord  with  international 
practice  for  the  Project.  For  government  agencies  implementing  the  nonrevenue-earning

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

29. 
The impact of the Project is sustained socioeconomic growth and improved living standards 
in the border areas of north Xinjiang (Altay Administrative District, Boertala Mongolian Autonomous 
Prefecture  [BMAP],  and  Yili  Kazak  Autonomous  Prefecture).  The  outcome  of  the  Project  is 
improved  municipal  infrastructure  and  a  better  living  and  ecological  environment  in  Alashankou 
land port, Kanas scenic region, and Yining City. 
 
B. 

Outputs 

30. 
The  Project  has  three  components  broken  down  into  13  subcomponents.  The  three 
components  are  (i)  Yining  City  roads  and  municipal  services  (component  I),  (ii)  Alashankou  land 
port  municipal  infrastructure  and  environmental  protection  (component  II),  and  (iii)  Kanas  scenic 
region infrastructure and environmental protection (component III). The Yining component seeks to 
improve the existing road infrastructure to assist commercial access to cross-border trade, improve 
urban living conditions, and expand roads and utility services into new development areas of the 
city  in  order  to  support  industrial  activity,  improve  the  local  economy,  and  increase  employment. 
The  Alashankou  component  will  develop  new  and  upgrade  existing  infrastructure  services  to 
improve  basic  living  conditions,  encourage  expansion  of  cross-border  trade,  expand  the  local 
economy, and protect the local environment from pollution. The Kanas component will provide new 
water  supply,  sanitation,  solid  waste  management,  and  road  network  infrastructure  in  order  to 
develop  its  local  economy  and  tourism,  improve  the  living  conditions  and  health  of  ethnic 
minorities,  and  protect  the  environment.12 A  summary  description  of  the  project  components  and 
subcomponents follows. (Supplementary Appendixes C,  D, and E provide technical details of the 
components.) 
 
31. 
Component  I  (Yining  City  roads  and  municipal  services)  includes  (i)  construction  of  four 
main roads, reconstruction of 33 local roads, and improvement of associated infrastructure (water 
supply,  wastewater  treatment,  heating,  telecommunications,  and  other  municipal  services);  and

collection stations, garbage collection containers, garbage trucks, street cleaning trucks, and snow 
clearing trucks). 
 
Component II (Alashankou land port municipal infrastructure and environmental protection) 
32. 
comprises (i) construction of 13 new roads and reconstruction of six existing roads, (ii) construction 
of a 60,000 cubic meters per day (m3/day) water treatment plant and associated raw water pipeline 
and  water  distribution  pipelines,  (iii)  construction  of  a  21,000  m3/day  wastewater  treatment  plant 
and  associated  effluent  storage  tank  and  collection  pipeline,  (iv)  construction  of  heating  stations 
and heating pipelines, (v) construction and installation of environmental sanitation and solid waste 
treatment  facilities  (public  toilets,  garbage  collection  points, dustbins,  garbage  trucks,  and  a  solid 
waste landfill site), and (vi) planting and irrigation of ecological protective forests. 
 
Component  III  (Kanas  scenic  region  infrastructure  and  environmental  protection)  includes 
33. 
(i)  construction  of  village  roads  and  village  parking  areas,  (ii)  construction  of  a  300  m3/day  water 
supply  system  and  associated  connection  and  distribution  pipelines,  (iii)  construction  of  a  200 
m3/day  wastewater  treatment  system  and  associated  connection  and  collection  pipelines,  (iv) 
construction and installation of environmental sanitation and solid waste treatment facilities (public 
toilets,  garbage  collection  stations,  dustbins,  garbage  trucks,  and  a  solid  waste  landfill  site),  and 
(v) rehabilitation of vegetation along roadsides.

include  project  management  consulting  services  and 

Special Features 

training  during 

35. 
Support for a Remote and Poor Region. The Project is the first ADB-financed municipal 
infrastructure development and environmental management project in Xinjiang, which is one of the 
poorest  and  most  remote  regions  in  the  PRC.  It  will  support  economic  growth  and  poverty 
reduction and facilitate regional trade between the PRC and the CARs, and this will raise the living 
standards and improve the environment. It covers a range of settlements—a medium-sized city, a 
small  but  rapidly  expanding  land  port,  and  four  villages  in  a  fast-growing  tourist attraction  area—
and is aimed to serve as a pilot for similar activities in other cities and areas in Xinjiang. 
 
36. 
Proactive Approach to Environmental Management. The Project will support XUARG in 
pioneering  environmental  protection  planning  and  related  investments  before  rapid  economic 
growth  and  environmental  degradation  occur.  This  will ensure  that  the  environment  in  one  of  the 
most pristine regions of the PRC is protected. The aim is to avoid the pollution problems currently 
being  faced  by  rapidly  growing  cities  in  the  coastal  provinces  and  the  consequent  significant 
negative  impacts  on  the  economy,  environment,  and  health  of  the  population.  The  Alashankou 
component will support water resource conservation through reuse of treated effluent for irrigation 
in a semidesert area. 
 
Traffic  Planning  and  Management.  In  addition  to  improvement  of  the  existing  road 
37. 
network and accessibility, the Yining component will improve city traffic management, including (i) 
traffic planning and traffic control development, and (ii) a traffic management scheme focusing on 
signage and traffic signals to improve traffic flow and road safety for vehicles and pedestrians. 

 

 10 

 

Support  for  Ethnic  Minority  Women.  The Project will also be complemented by a grant 
38. 
($150,000),  financed  by  the  Gender  and  Development  Fund,  for  the  Kanas  Women’s  Enterprise 
Development  Project  (Appendix  4).  It  aims  to  support  capacity  building  in  local  tourism  and 
demonstration projects in health and hygiene for ethnic minority women in the Kanas component of 
the  Project.  The  objectives  of  the  grant  are  to  (i)  build  local  participation  in  the  growing  cultural 
tourism  opportunities  emerging  in  Kanas,  (ii)  support  small-scale  infrastructure  to  assist  in 
marketing  and  storage  of  local  products,  and  (iii)  increase  public  participation  in  accessing  the 
benefits  of  health  and  hygiene  infrastructure  improvements  provided  by  the  Project.  The  Kanas 
project management office (PMO) and implementing agency will implement and manage the grant 
project.

Financing Plan 

The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $105.0  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
40. 
resources to finance 55% of the cost of the Project. The loan will cover (i) civil works, (ii) equipment 
and  supplies,  (iii)  project  consulting  services  and  training,  and  (iv)  financial  charges  on  the  loan 
during construction. The Government will finance contingencies. The Altay Prefecture government, 

  

 

11 

BMAP government, and Yining municipal government will provide counterpart funding through tax 
and nontax revenues, for which they have provided commitment letters to XUARG and ADB. The 
financing  plan  for  the  Project  is  summarized  in  Table  2,  with  details  provided  in  Appendix  5. 
Supplementary  Appendix  F  provides  details  of  the  cost  estimates  and  financing  plans  for  each 
component. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending 
facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum, and such other terms and conditions set forth 
in the draft loan agreement. The Government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision 
to  borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility  on  the  basis  of  these  terms  and  conditions, 
and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own  independent  decision  and  not  made  in 
reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
41. 
The borrower of the loan is the PRC. The loan will be entirely made available to XUARG. 
Different portions of the loan proceeds will be made available to the concerned prefecture and/or 
municipal  governments  and  then  to  the  implementing  agencies.  The  terms  and  conditions  of  the 
loan proceeds transferred within the government system will be the same as those of the ADB loan, 
with  the  concerned  prefecture  and/or  municipal  governments  bearing  the  interest  and  exchange 
rate  variation  risk.  The  BMAP  government  will  onlend  its  portion  of  the  loan  to  the  Alashankou 
Land  Port  Construction  Company  Limited  (ALPCC)  under  an  onlending  agreement  which  will 
contain the same terms and conditions as those of the ADB loan, with ALPCC bearing the interest 
and  exchange  rate  variation  risk  and  the  applicable  obligations  and  requirements  in  the  Project 
Agreement. Appendix 6 shows the flow of funds and onlending arrangements.

2. 

Implementation Period 

43. 
The Project will be implemented over 5 years from mid-2008 to mid-2013 (Appendix 8). The 
estimate of the implementation period is based on the project scope, the construction technology 
requirements,  and  the  climate  conditions.  The  schedule  is  considered  realistic  and  achievable 
because  (i)  the  executing  agency  has  World  Bank  project  implementation  experience,  (ii)  the 
project  implementation  structure  is  in  place,  and  (iii)  preparatory  works  are  under  way.  ADB’s 
successful  experience  with  similar  projects  in  the  PRC,  combined  with  the  knowledge  and 
experience  of  XUARG  in  municipal  infrastructure  and  environmental  improvement  projects,  also 
indicates that the schedule is realistic and achievable. 
 

3. 

Procurement and Consulting Services 

Goods,  works,  and  services  financed  under  the  loan  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with 
44. 
ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Preliminary  contract 
packages have been formulated in consultation with the implementing agencies and a procurement 
capacity  assessment  of  the  executing  agency,  PMOs,  and  implementing  agencies  has  been 
undertaken  (Supplementary  Appendix  H).  Contracts  for  goods  estimated  to  cost  $1.0 million  or 
more  and  contracts  for  works  estimated  to  cost  $10.0  million  or  more  will  be  procured  using 
international competitive bidding procedures. Contracts for goods and works estimated to cost less 
than  the  above  international  competitive  bidding  thresholds  but  more  than  $100,000  will  be 
procured  on  the  basis  of  national  competitive  bidding  procedures  in  accordance  with  the  PRC 
Tendering and Bidding Law, subject to modifications agreed to with ADB. Contracts for goods and 
works estimated to cost $100,000 or less will be procured using shopping procedures. More details 
of the procurement plan are provided in Appendix 9. 
 
45. 
The Project includes provision for funding for international and national consulting services 
to  support  the  Xinjiang  and  city  PMOs  and  implementing  agencies  in  project  implementation  and 
management  and  institutional  capacity  building.  A  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  in  accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) using the 
standard  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  (80%  quality  and  20%  cost)  and  simplified 
technical proposal. The consulting services will cover (i) support of the Xinjiang and city PMOs and 
implementing  agencies  in  project  preparation  and  management,  (ii)  development  of  the  project 
performance  management  system  (PPMS),  (iii) transport  planning  and  traffic  control  for  Yining 
PMO  and  implementing  agency,  (iv)  financial  management,  (v)  social  development,  (vi) 
environmental  management,  (vii)  O&M,  and  (viii) institutional  strengthening.  Capacity  building  for 
the PMOs and implementing agencies will be achieved through consultant inputs, training courses 
provided  by  universities,  specialized  institutes  and  firms,  in-country  and/or  overseas  study  visits, 
and  acquisition  of  additional  equipment  financed  from  the  loan.  To  assist  the  PMOs  and 
implementing agencies in expediting project implementation, one international project management 
and  procurement  specialist  (1  person-month)  and  one  national  project  management  and 
procurement  specialist  (2  person-months)  will  be  engaged  individually  prior  to  recruitment  of  the 
consulting  firm.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  are  in  Supplementary 
Appendix I.

7. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 

49. 
The  Xinjiang  PMO  will  coordinate  with  the  city  PMOs  to  prepare  semiannual  progress 
reports indicating (i) progress made, (ii) problems encountered during the period under review, (iii) 
steps taken or proposed to remedy the problems, (iv) the proposed program of activities, and (v) 
progress expected in the next 3 months. The implementing agencies will keep records to allow the 
identification  of  goods  and  services  financed  from  the  loan  proceeds  following  accounting 
principles and practices prescribed by the Accounting Law of the PRC. This law requires that the 
financial statements generally follow recognized accounting standards. The implementing agencies 
will  set  up  and  maintain  separate  project  accounts  and  records.  The  financial  statements  of  the 
project accounts and the annual corporate financial statements for implementing agencies will be 
subject  to  external  audit  by  the  audit  bureau  of  the  cities  and  areas  concerned,  XUARG  audit 
bureau,  and  the  state  audit  bureau.  The  audits  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  PRC  audit 
regulations  and  must  meet  ADB  requirements.  A  separate  auditor’s  opinion  on  the  use  of  the 
imprest account and statement of expenditure will be part of the audit reports. The implementing 
agencies’  annual  audited  financial  statements  and  audited  project  accounts  will  be  submitted  to 
ADB no later than 6 months after the end of the fiscal year throughout the implementation period. 
XUARG and the implementing agencies will submit reports and information to ADB concerning the 
use of the loan proceeds, project implementation, and implementing agency performance. These 
reports will include (i) semiannual progress reports on project implementation, (ii) annual reports, 
and  (iii)  a  project  completion  report  not  later  than  3 months  after  the  completion  of  the  project 
facilities. 
 

8. 

Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 

The  PPMS  indicators,  their  relevance,  and  monitoring  practicalities  have  been  discussed 
50. 
with  the  Xinjiang  and  city  PMOs  and  implementing  agencies  during  project  preparation.  The 
indicators are based on the monitoring indicators in the design and monitoring framework. At the 
start of implementation of the Project, the Xinjiang and city PMOs and implementing agencies, with 
the loan implementation consultant’s assistance, will develop comprehensive PPMS procedures to 
generate  data  systematically  on  the  inputs  and  outputs  of  the  subcomponents,  as  well  as  the 
indicators to be used to measure the project impact. The Xinjiang and city PMOs will (i) refine the 
PPMS,  (ii) confirm  achievable  targets,  (iii)  finalize  monitoring  and  recording  arrangements,  and 
(iv) establish systems and procedures no later than 6 months after loan effectiveness. 
 

9. 

Project Review 

In addition to joint project reviews carried out at least once a year, ADB, XUARG, and the 
51. 
implementing  agencies  will  undertake  a  comprehensive  midterm  review  2 years  after  the  start  of 
project  implementation.  This  will  include  a  detailed  evaluation  of  the  scope,  implementation

policy reform and capacity-building measures. Feedback from the PPMS activities will be analyzed. 
 

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Social  Aspects.  Xinjiang  is  a  low-income  region  compared  with  the  coastal  provinces. 
52. 
Yining City (home to 93% of all project beneficiaries) is a low-income area with a mean per capita 
income  less  than  half  that  of  the  Xinjiang  urban  area  average.  The  Project  will  benefit  about 
471,400 people, 10% of whom are poor. Major socioeconomic impacts include (i) improvement of 

  

 

15 

living  standards  through  provision  of  essential  public  infrastructure,  (ii) improvement  of  public 
health  through  infrastructure  and  environmental  upgrading,  (iii) improvement  of  the  quality  and 
affordability  of  basic  services,  and  (iv)  significant  job  creation.  Approximately  half  of  the  project 
beneficiaries of the constructed infrastructure and environmental improvement will be women. 
 
53. 
The  poverty  and  social  assessment  has  identified  several  major  areas  where  the  Project 
will  benefit  the  poor  and  disadvantaged  groups.  Provision  of  water  supply  and  wastewater 
infrastructure will have quantifiable impacts on public health in terms of savings made on medical 
consultations  and  purchase  of  medicines.  The  Project  will  reduce  the  incidence  of  water-  and 
vector-related  diseases  and  improve  the  living  conditions  of  the  population.  The  health  impact 
analysis is in Supplementary Appendix J. The infrastructure improvements will reduce time spent 
on  domestic  work  (largely  undertaken  by  women),  such  as  fetching  and  disposal  of  water, 
cleaning, and caring for children, the sick, and the elderly. Connections to district heating systems 
will  enable  households  to  save  significantly  on  purchases  of  heating  coal.  Yining  City  offers 
subsidies  for  various  public  utilities  to  poor  households  receiving  minimum  standard  of  living 
allowance. Jobs created through the Project, during both the construction and O&M phases, will (i) 
help address the significant unemployment in both Kanas and Yining, (ii) provide new skills to local 
workers, and (iii) stimulate a number of secondary industries. The summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Appendix 10; details are in Supplementary Appendix K. 
 
54. 
The  Project  is  classified  as  category  A  for  resettlement.  For  the  Yining  component,  which 
will  necessitate  relatively  large  amounts  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  a  full  resettlement 
plan has been prepared based on ADB resettlement policy and PRC guidelines. Under the Kanas 
component,  upgraded  village  roads  will  follow  their  existing  alignments.  Consequently,  the 
resettlement impacts are very slight and a short resettlement plan has been prepared. Although the 
Alashankou component will occupy a large amount of state-owned land, the land is barren and no 
people  will  be  affected,  therefore  no  resettlement  plan  is  required.  Land  acquisition  and  house 
demolition  in  Kanas  and  Yining  will  directly  affect  a  total  of  2,021  persons  comprising  354 
households (1,857 persons), 100 small businesses, and an enterprise (164 persons). A budget of 
$9.86  million  has  been  allocated  for  all  activities  related  to  land  acquisition,  relocation,  and 
compensation. The Yining and Kanas PMOs have endorsed and disclosed the resettlement plans 
to  the  affected  persons  and  the  resettlement  plans  were  posted  in  the  neighborhood  committee 
and/or village offices in mid-October 2007. The summary resettlement plan is in Appendix 11. The 
Yining and Kanas PMOs will employ a national external monitor to (i) review resettlement progress 
and  the  general  welfare  of  those  affected  every  6  months,  (ii)  recommend  ways  to  resolve  any 
issues or problems, (iii) provide advice to implementing agencies and local officials, and (iv) submit 
reports on these matters to ADB. 
 
Xinjiang  is  a  region  with  a  high  number  and  proportion  of  ethnic  minorities  (24%  of  the 
55. 
population in Alashankou, 97% in Kanas, and 82% in Yining). The Project is classified as category 
A  for  ethnic  minorities.  The  socioeconomic  analysis  has  shown  that  ethnic  minorities  are  more 
likely to be poor than the general population in both Kanas and Yining, where land acquisition and 
resettlement  will  significantly  affect  ethnic  minorities.  In  line  with  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous 
Peoples  (1998)  and  PRC  requirements,  the  Yining  and  Kanas  PMOs  have  each  prepared  and 
endorsed  an  ethnic  minority  development  plan  (EMDP)  for  the  respective  component  and  have 
disclosed  the  EMDPs  to  the  affected  persons  at  public  meetings  and  for  posting  in  the 
neighborhood committee and/or village offices in mid-October 2007. The EMDPs set out measures 
and  identify  the  budget  sources  needed  in  order  to  enhance  positive  impacts  and  mitigate  any 
negative impacts ethnic minorities may experience. Importantly, the EMDPs also set out a detailed 
participation  plan  to  ensure  that  ethnic  minorities  are  heard  and  to  inform  project  design, 
implementation,  and  actions  to  specifically  target  ethnic  minorities.  The  summary  EMDP  is  in 
Appendix 12.

Financial  Aspects.  A  financial  analysis  of  the  Project  was  undertaken  for  the  revenue-
56. 
generating  water  supply,  wastewater,  and  heating  subcomponents  in  Alashankou.  Financial 
sustainability  analysis  was  undertaken  for  the  nonrevenue-generating  roads,  environmental 
sanitation  and  solid  waste  management,  vegetation 
forest 
subcomponents.  Financial  projections  take  into  account  the  impact  on  receivables  and  costs  of 
operational  improvements,  reductions  in  unaccounted-for  water,  and  gradual  increase  in  tariffs. 
The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  for  the  water  supply  subcomponent  in  Alashankou, 
computed on an after-tax basis, is 6.9%; for the wastewater subcomponent it is 5.8%, and for the 
heating subcomponent it is 11.2%. The FIRRs compare favorably with the weighted average cost 
of capital in real terms of 3.2% for the water supply and wastewater subcomponents and 3.1% for 
the  heating  subcomponent.  The  sensitivity  analyses  include  examination  of  the  risk  that  project 
costs  will  increase  by  10.0%,  or  that  revenues  will  decrease  by  10.0%  without  implementation  of 
the  required  water,  wastewater,  and  heating  tariffs;  the  FIRR  is  5.9%  for  water  supply,  4.7%  for 
wastewater, and 10.5% for heating. The summary financial analysis is in Appendix 13, and details 
are in Supplementary Appendix L. 
 
57. 
The current water, wastewater and heating tariffs in Alashankou are sufficient to cover the 
O&M costs and depreciation of existing facilities. Tariffs will need to be increased when the ADB-
financed  facilities  come  into  operation.  As  the  population  base  in  Alashankou  is  small,  tariff 
increases to achieve full cost recovery will take time. The Government has assured that (i) tariffs 
will  be  increased  in  phases,  taking  into  account  affordability  factors;  and  (ii)  subsidies  will  be 
provided  to  ensure  sustainable  O&M  of  the  project  facilities.  The  Project  will  provide  capacity 
building  on  tariff  reforms  and  tariff  setting  in  Alashankou.  An  affordability  analysis  of  the 
subcomponents showed that the combined full-cost water supply, wastewater, and heating tariffs 
are  4%  of  average  household  income  in  Alashankou.  There  are  currently  no  tariffs  on  water  and 
wastewater  in  Kanas.  Provision  of  utility  services  in  the  project  villages  is  fully  financed  by  the 
Government through tourism revenues. As the majority of the residents in the project villages are 
poor, the Government has indicated that it will not charge tariffs on the villagers. Notwithstanding 
that,  the  Project  will  provide  capacity  building  on  financial  management  to  ensure  that  sufficient 
funds are allocated for sustainable O&M of the project facilities. 
 
58. 
Financial  sustainability  of  the  nonrevenue-generating  subcomponents  was  determined. 
Affordability  by  the  implementing  agencies  was  assessed  by  comparing  identified  financing 
sources with the annual funds required for capital expenditures during project implementation, and 
O&M  and  debt  services  during  operation.  Forecast  debt  service  and  O&M  costs  for  the  Yining, 
Alashankou, and Kanas components were compared as a percentage of relevant annual revenues. 
These  were  found  to  be  6%  for  Yining,  1%  for  Alashankou,  and  2%  for  Kanas,  indicating 
acceptable  fiscal  risk,  particularly  in  light  of  increasing  government  revenues.  During  the  peak 
project implementation period, counterpart funds for Yining will not exceed 6% of the annual capital 
expenditure budget; the figure for Alashankou is 1%, and for Kanas 3%. The Project is considered 
both financially viable and sustainable.

60. 
Economic  Aspects.  The  economic  analysis  for  the  Project  covers  (i)  the  economic 
rationale for public intervention, (ii) the goals of the investment plan, and (iii) the design of the plan. 
The economic rationale is sound as the Project will (i) support XUARG to promote development in 
cities  and  towns  in  a  more  coordinated  and  cost-effective  manner,  and  (ii)  bring  about  more 
sustainable  investments  in  infrastructure,  which  aim  to  support  inclusive  economic  growth  and 
improve  the  quality  of  life.  The  economic  analysis  also  evaluates  the  subcomponents  relative  to 
least-cost  analysis  criteria  and  standard  benefit–cost  analysis.  The  results  of  the  economic 
analysis  indicate  that  the  three  components  are  economically  viable  and  that  they  stand  up  to 
sensitivity  analyses  where  costs  increase  and  benefits  decrease.  The  economic  internal  rate  of 
return  under  the  base  case  for  the  Alashankou  component  is  15.7%,  for  Kanas  18.7%,  and  for 
Yining  20.3%.  All  are  above  the  12.0%  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  under  various 
sensitivity analyses, including increase in costs and decrease in benefits; delay of implementation 
by  1  year  does  not  have  a  significant  impact.  A  summary  economic  analysis  is  in  Appendix  14, 
while the detailed economic analysis is in Supplementary Appendix N. 
 
61. 
Environmental  Aspects.  The  Project  is  classified  as  environment  category  A.  Extensive 
public  consultations  involving  surveys,  meetings  with  stakeholders,  and  focus-group  discussions 
were undertaken during project preparation. The summary environmental impact assessment was 
circulated to ADB’s Board of Directors and posted on the ADB website on 22 October 2007. 
 
62. 
The  Project  will  improve  the  living  environment  for  the  residents  in  Alashankou  land  port, 
Kanas scenic region, and Yining City. Construction of the water treatment plant and use of water 
from a reservoir in Alashankou will prevent the overuse of groundwater and remove a factor that 
limits the economic development of the land port. Provision of sanitation facilities—including public 
toilets,  garbage  bins,  garbage  storage  and  transfer  stations,  and  sanitary  landfills—will  have 
environmental  and  public  health  benefits.  This  is  particularly  important  for  Kanas,  where  the 
tourism  industry  is  growing  rapidly.  If  sanitation  facilities  are  not  in  place  in  time,  there  will  be 
adverse environmental impacts in the natural reserve. 
 
63. 
The project cities and areas presently lack an adequate road network. Construction of new 
roads will improve connectivity within the project cities and areas. Upgrading of existing dirt roads 
will  improve  the  currently  dusty  conditions  during  the  dry  season  and  muddy  conditions  during 
rainy  and  snow  seasons—a  major  constraint  to  efficient  and  effective  transport  and  an 
inconvenience to the residents. The roadworks will also provide opportunities to install or upgrade 
municipal services—including pipelines, cables, or conduits for water supply, wastewater collection, 
power,  heating,  and  telecommunications—and  will  bring  environmental  and  social  benefits  to  the 
population. 
 
Importantly,  the  Project  provides  an  opportunity  for  XUARG  to  put  in  place  sound 
64. 
environmental  management  systems  in  border  cities  and  towns  before  economic  development 
accelerates, and establish adequate institutional capacity in environmental management to ensure 
environmental sustainability for future development. 
 
65. 
During  construction,  dust  from  construction  sites,  noise  from  powered  mechanical 
equipment, wastewater, solid waste, and construction traffic are expected to be the major adverse 
impacts. Good project management and effective mitigation measures have been recommended. 

 

 18 

 

With the implementation of these measures, the impacts will be mitigated to acceptable levels. An 
environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  has  been  developed  for  the  design,  construction,  and 
operational  phases  of  the  Project.  The  EMP  includes  the  institutional  strengthening  for 
implementing the mitigation measures and undertaking the monitoring requirements. The EMP will 
be  further  developed  as  the  Project  progresses  to  provide  more  details  so  that  all  mitigation 
requirements are met. 
 
66. 
Project Risks and Mitigation Measures. The Project does not have any unusual technical 
risks.  Conventional  engineering  designs  with  proven  records  of  reliable  performance  will  be 
adopted  for  road  construction,  installation  of  municipal  services  along  roads,  water  supply  and 
wastewater  management,  solid  waste  treatment,  environmental  sanitation,  heating,  landscaping, 
and  ecological  protective  planting.  During  project  implementation,  the  loan  implementation 
consultant will support the PMOs and implementing agencies to ensure that equipment and works 
comply with the design requirements and quality assurances. 
 
67. 
The following risks could affect timely implementation, economic viability, and realization of 
benefits  of  the  Project:  (i)  failure  to  implement  institutional  strengthening  for  effective  project 
implementation  and  management;  (ii)  lack  of  proper  O&M  of  project  facilities;  (iii)  major 
amendments  and  changes  to  the  master  plans  in  the  project  cities  and  areas;  (iv)  delay  in 
completion of related projects (such as the ring roads in Kanas) that will provide better access to 
the villages, and a new reservoir in Alashankou as an alternate raw water source; (v) delay in the 
provision of counterpart funding; (vi) failure to establish or increase water, wastewater, and heating 
tariffs  in  Alashankou  to  meet  cost-recovery  targets;  and  (vii)  unforeseen  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  issues,  which  could  hamper  the  efficient  implementation  of  the  project  works  and 
restoration of livelihoods of affected persons. 
 
68. 
Risks (i) and (ii) will be mitigated through provision of institutional capacity building for the 
Xinjiang  and  city  PMOs  and  implementing  agencies  with  support  of  the  loan  implementation 
consultant.  Risks  (iii)  and  (iv)  will  be  mitigated  by  synchronization  of  the  project  design  and 
implementation  schedules  with  other  planned  projects.  The  three  project  governments  have 
provided specific loan assurances that are covenanted in the Loan Agreement. Risks (v) and (vi) 
will  be  mitigated  through  covenanted  assurances  from  the  three  project  governments  on  the 
provision  of  counterpart  funding  and  from  the  BMAP  government  on  regular  tariff  reviews  and 
increases. Risk (vii) will be mitigated by strengthening of the internal monitoring and supervision by 
the Xinjiang and city PMOs and implementing agencies, and by engagement of a qualified external 
agency to monitor and evaluate resettlement.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

A. 

Urban  Development  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and  the  Western  Region 
Development Strategy 

from  underinvestment  relative 

traffic  management  now  suffer 

 
Prior  to  the  late  1970s,  the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  solely 
1. 
funded  its  urban  services.  Infrastructure  development  was  poor,  vehicle  ownership  was  low,  and 
there  was  no  wastewater  treatment.  The  rapid  development  since  then  has  affected  the 
environment  and  municipal  services,  and  requires  coherent  planning  and  management.  Road 
to  road 
maintenance  and 
construction,  and  pedestrian  and  nonmotorized  transport  is  marginalized,  posing  safety  hazards. 
Growth  of  car  ownership,  an  increase  in  road  accidents,  and  the  lack  of  parking  management 
compound the situation. Without prompt mitigation measures, the quality of life and the efficiency of 
economies will be reduced. Capacity building and institutional development in urban planning and 
management is important to ensuring sustainability of the infrastructure. Among the environmental 
protection tasks in the Premier’s 2007 Report on the Work of the Government,1 priority is given to 
the  development  of  urban  public  transport  systems,  employment  of  comprehensive  economic 
measures  to  facilitate  environmental  work,  and  increase  of  funding  to  support  construction  of 
facilities for treating urban sewage and household wastes. 
 
2. 
The  PRC’s  western  region  has  not  benefited  as  much  as  the  coastal  regions  from  rapid 
growth and reforms. Infrastructure and service provision cannot match increasing demand, thereby 
hindering  investment,  degrading  the  environment,  and  limiting  growth  opportunities.  In  1999,  the 
Government  launched  the  western  region  development  strategy  to  promote  balanced  growth, 
stimulate development, and raise the living standard in the western region. This strategy is still a 
major  thrust  of  its  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (11FYP)  for  2006–2010.  The  focus  now  is  on  (i) 
improving border facilities, (ii) strengthening cooperation and trade with neighboring countries, (iii) 
improving  infrastructure,  (iv)  protecting  the  environment,  and  (v)  encouraging  private  sector 
investment. The Asian Development Bank is actively supporting this initiative. 
 
Sixty two percent of the population of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region (Xinjiang), in the 
3. 
northwest  of  the  PRC  comes  from  46  ethnic  minority  groups.  Sharing  5,600  kilometers  (km)  of 
border  with  eight  countries,  Xinjiang  is  the  gateway  between  the  PRC  and  the  Central  Asian 
republics, with which it has many cultural similarities and economic complementarities. Its history 
and  ethnic  culture  has  promoted  tourism  development  and  its  rich  natural  resources  provide  a 
sound basis for development. Considering these advantages, in order to maximize the potential for 
growth and raise living standards, the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region government focuses its 
development  strategy  on  its  potential  role  in  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation 
(CAREC) Program, and in its 11FYP accorded high priority to sustainable economic development 
through construction and upgrade of the infrastructure in major border ports, while at the same time 
protecting  the  environment.  Xinjiang’s  border  cities  face  the  challenge  of  increasing  utility 
demands,  as  do  many  other  areas in  the  PRC.  The  lack  of  transportation  planning  leads  to  poor 
provision  for  infrastructure  and  environmental  protection  and  has  an  impact  on  the  transport 
strategy,  public  transport  provisions,  and  road  safety  considerations  for  pedestrians,  cyclists, 
drivers, and passengers. Poor traffic management contributes to a reduction in accessibility and an 
increase in traffic accidents. Old and fragile utilities and inadequate infrastructure provision result in 
poor standards and frequent service failures. 
 
4. 
The  Project  will  support  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  policies  through  provision  of 
sustainable municipal infrastructure and increased economic activities and employment, and will (i) 
promote its CAREC strategy, (ii) protect the environment by controlling and reducing pollution, and 
(iii) improve health and living conditions. The Project component areas are located near the border 
with  Kazakhstan.  The  Alashankou  component 
infrastructure  and
