includes  wide-ranging 

  

Appendix 2 

27 

Roads 

environmental improvements that will strengthen its position as a gateway for traffic to and from the 
countries  of  Central  Asia.  Kanas,  with  a  top-ranked  nature  reserve,  requires  provision  of 
infrastructure,  environmental  protection  measures  for  four  villages,  and  environmental  restoration 
from  damage  caused  by  poor  tourism  management.  The  Yining  component  will  include  upgrade 
and expansion of the road network and associated utilities. 
 
B. 
 
5. 
The road subcomponents will fulfill functional requirements of individual areas. Apart from 
improving accessibility within the areas, they provide an opportunity for the extension of municipal 
services to existing and proposed premises. Yining is a medium-sized city of 438,000 people and is 
undergoing  expansion  and  transformation.  In  2004,  its  passenger  trips  reached  19.1  million 
persons and freight traffic 456,000 tons. It has 17 arterial roads, 2.3 million square meters of paved 
roads, and 434 narrow and unpaved alleys. The road network includes radial and ring roads in the 
old district in a grid. The city government has decided to retain the characteristics of the old district 
and  upgrade  the  road  network  to  improve  accessibility.  The  Project  includes  construction  and 
upgrading of four arterial roads and paving of alleys in 33 areas within the old district, together with 
associated utilities. Upgrading of two arterial roads that link to the ring road system will provide an 
opportunity to develop the new areas to the west of the old town. A new road and the extension of 
an existing arterial road will cater for a new railway station to the north. New and upgraded roads 
will  improve  the  traffic  conditions  and  public  transport.  Road  safety  and  traffic  management  are 
also  areas  of  concern.  Capacity  building  in  urban  planning  and  traffic  engineering  will  improve 
traffic management capability.  
 
6. 
Alashankou land port’s present population is under 30,000 people, with a target of 80,000 
by 2020. The main employment is for services related to the land port, such as port management, 
cargo  handling,  processing  of  raw  materials,  and  supporting facilities.  Many  roads  built  when  the 
land  port  opened  in  1990  are  due  for  rehabilitation;  most  have  no  walkways  and  amenity  strips. 
The Project comprises 13 new roads and 6 upgraded roads on existing road base compacted by 
road traffic, totaling 29.3 km in the central district, plus roadside utilities. The Northern Ring Road 
will connect to a railway line; Youhao Road will be used for cross-border cargo traffic in the short 
term, and the Western Ring Road will be used in the long term. The existing and proposed road 
network  in  the  master  plan  follows strictly  a  grid  system  without  a  clear  network  hierarchy;  traffic 
control  will  become  difficult  as  traffic  levels  increase.  The  Project  includes  upgrading  of  existing 
roads  and  provision  of  new  roads  for  future  residential,  cargo  storage,  trade,  and  office 
administration uses, and this will support cross-border trade.  
 
7. 
Kanas  scenic  region’s  road  subcomponent  covers  three  of  the  four  villages  under  the 
Project,  the  master  plans  of  which  are  being  reviewed  by  the  Altay  Prefecture  government.  The 
present roads—unpaved, narrow, and in poor condition—are dusty on sunny days and muddy on 
rainy  days  in  summer  and  are  completely  blocked  by  ice  in  winter.  Existing  and  new  roads  are 
proposed  to  be  paved  along  tracks  at  a  gentle  gradient  with  materials  in  harmony  with  the 
environment, enabling vehicles to serve the villages at all times. Street lighting will be installed. The 
Project also includes parking areas and stabilization of adjacent slopes. 
 
C. 
 
The  water  source  in  Alashankou  is  underground  water.  The  annual  quantity  that  can  be 
8. 
replenished is 4.67 million cubic meters (m3); the quantity now extracted is 5.18 million m3 due to 
rapid  development.  This  overextraction  has  lowered  the  water  level  and  the  water  quality  has 
deteriorated.  The  present  water  demand  of  the  land  port  of  14,200  m3/day  is  forecast  to  reach 
60,000  m3/day  by  2015;  the  supply  from  the  present  water  treatment  plant  is  only  5,000  m3/day. 
The Project includes a water treatment plant  and inlet distribution pipelines to meet the needs of 
the land port’s development and of the residents. The water supply for the Kanas subcomponent is 
in Tiereketi Village, among the hills upstream of the Haba River. The village has no water supply 

Water Supply, Wastewater Treatment, Sanitation, and Waste Management 

 

 28 

Appendix 2 

system;  farmers  and  herdsmen  currently  use  spring  water  and  unhygienic  river  water.  As  rainfall 
and snowfall is abundant and the Tiereketi River, a tributary of the Haba River, flows through the 
village,  the  underground  and  surface  water  resources  can  meet  the  demands  of  villagers  and 
tourists  in  the  coming  years.  The  Project  includes  water  extraction  works,  high-level  water  tanks, 
water  supply,  and  household  connection  pipelines  to  supply  water  to  the  villagers,  who  live  at 
various levels in the river valley. 
 
9. 
There is no wastewater treatment facility in Alashankou and the sewage pipes serve only 
70% of the demand. The Project includes interceptor pipes laid with the roads and a wastewater 
treatment  plant.  The  treated  effluent  will  be  carried  to  an  effluent  storage  tank  and  used  for 
irrigation of desert woodland. There are also no wastewater treatment facilities or sewage pipes in 
villages in Kanas. The Project includes a buried wastewater treatment system, sewage pipes, and 
household connection pipes in Tiereketi Village. The treated effluent will meet discharge standards 
for irrigation of forests and pastures. 
 
10. 
Yining’s  environmental  sanitation  subcomponent  includes  waste  collection  and  disposal 
facilities.  Alashankou  has  no  solid  waste  treatment,  collection,  or  transfer  facilities;  garbage  is 
delivered to a location with high groundwater level and, without anti-seepage measures, it pollutes 
the  groundwater.  The Project  includes  public  toilets,  garbage  collection  points,  dustbins,  garbage 
trucks,  and  a  solid  waste  landfill  site.  In  Kanas,  along  with  tourism  development,  some 
environmental  sanitation  and  refuse  collection  facilities  have  been  built,  but  it  is  limited  to  a  few 
receiving  bases.  Most  villages  and  tourist  spots  have  no  dustbins,  refuse  collection  points, 
environmentally friendly toilets, or a proper landfill; the residents randomly bury or dispose of the 
refuse, which pollutes the environment. The Project includes public toilets, garbage trucks, refuse 
collection stations, dustbins, and a sanitary landfill. 
 
D. 
 
11. 
Alashankou is in a semidesert area. In its urban area the landscaping ratio is less than 20%, 
below  the  60%  laid  down  in  the  master  plan.  The  irrigation  pipes  are  aging,  and  irrigation  of  the 
landscaped  areas  strains  the  inadequate  water  sources.  The  wastewater  treatment  plant  of  the 
Project will discharge treated effluent to be used for irrigation of desert woodland, thereby avoiding 
pollution of groundwater and conserving water sources. The Project also includes replacement of 
irrigation  pipes  and  irrigation  of  ecological protective  forests.  In  Kanas, vegetation  along  many  of 
the  hilly  roads  has  been  damaged,  exposing  the  underlying  soil,  causing  landslides  and  erosion, 
and endangering traffic. The Project includes reinstatement of vegetation along these roads. 
 
E. 
 
12. 
Broader  tourism  opportunities,  including  vacation,  recreation,  and  education  in  addition  to 
sightseeing,  have  been  introduced  into  the  industry  in  the  PRC.  Kanas  has  great  potential  for 
tourism  development.  It  possesses  beautiful  snowy  landscapes,  rivers,  lakes,  and  pastures,  and 
preserved frescoes from 4th century BC to 13th century AD and ruins of various nomadic tribes. It 
is the only home of the Tuvans, a branch of 2,000 Mongols, who inherit traditional beliefs, language, 
and  cultural  customs,  and  who  live  with  other  ethnic  minorities,  particularly  the  Kazaks.  Kanas 
attracted 760,000 tourist trips in 2006. Tourist numbers and tourism revenue have been increasing 
rapidly. The villages in Kanas are underdeveloped with poor roads and no proper wastewater and 
sanitation facilities. Rapid development has led to pollution of some pastures, rivers, and lakes by 
wastewater  and  refuse.  The  Project  includes  roads,  parking  areas,  water  supply  and  sewage 
treatment systems, waste facilities and landfill, and vegetation reinstatement to meet the residents’ 
basic needs, reinstate polluted landscapes, and support poverty reduction through environmentally 
sustainable tourism development.

KANAS WOMEN’S ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT 

 
1. 
Background.  The  Kanas  scenic  region  component  is  focused  on  improving  basic 
infrastructure  (roads,  water  supply,  wastewater  treatment,  environmental  sanitation,  and  solid 
waste  treatment)  and  environmental  protection.  The  environmental  protected  area  is  one  of  the 
premier tourism sites in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), and a priority development area for 
Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region and the PRC’s western region development strategy. With the 
provision of improved roads, potable water, and sanitation, the Project will provide direct benefits to 
communities  through  (i)  local  employment  during  construction,  (ii)  increased  year-round  access, 
(iii)  potentially  decreased  transport  costs,  and  (iv)  improved  health.  This  grant  is  focused  on 
providing  strategic  gender  and  development  support  to  the  Project  so  that  communities,  and 
particularly  ethnic  minority  women  (who  historically  have  had  little  interaction  with  the  market 
economy in the area), can gain long-term benefits from these improvements by participating in the 
new  tourism  economy  through  small-enterprise  development  highlighting  their  unique  cultural 
heritage, and utilizing the improved basic infrastructure. The grant also supports capacity building 
and a role in implementation for the local branch of the Women’s Federation, which is responsible 
for training and mobilization on gender issues at the local level. 
 
2. 
The  poverty  and  social  analysis  for  the  Project  has  found  that  ethnic  minority  women  in 
Kanas currently are rarely involved in the market economy, but have great interest in participating 
and are important potential economic contributors to their families. This grant seeks to provide the 
necessary  capacity  to  enable  women  to  participate  in  the  new  opportunities  that  the  project 
infrastructure  improvements  will  help  create.  It  focuses  on  building  capacity  at  the  local  level  for 
management and marketing of cultural tourism and integrating women’s traditional knowledge on 
handicrafts,  local  foods,  and  hospitality  management  to  support  livelihood  and  economic 
development.  The  grant  supports demonstration  projects  in  health  and  hygiene  to  help  maximize 
the  positive  impacts  of  the  improved  water  and  sanitation  infrastructure.  It  also  supports  the 
development of capacity of the Women’s Federation and training materials on ethnic minorities and 
cultural tourism that can benefit other areas as well. 
 
The  grant  is  directly  related  to  the  Xinjiang  Municipal  Infrastructure  and  Environmental 
3. 
Improvement Project and responds to gender issues raised in the poverty and social analysis and 
ethnic  minority  development  plan  conducted  for  the  Project.  It  supports  the  PRC’s  goal  of 
development of the western region and support of balanced growth and poverty reduction in one of 
the  poorest  and  most  remote  regions  of  the  PRC.  It  will  also  serve  as  an  important  pilot  of  the 
development  of  cultural tourism  in  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region,  where  tourism  is  a  major 
contributor  to  the  local  economy.  The  grant  directly  addresses  (i)  the  focal  area  in  the  country 
partnership strategy of  promotion of rural development; and (ii) issues raised in the PRC country 
gender  assessment  of  (a)  encouragement  of  women’s  entrepreneurship,  (b)  empowerment  of 
women  to  participate  in  community  development,  (c)  gender  mainstreaming  in  projects,  and  (d) 
support  to  women’s  organizations.  The  activities  are  in  line  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s 
Policy on Gender and Development (1998), which, among other things, calls for bringing women’s 
participation in decision-making and development activities into the mainstream. 
 
Objective.  The  objective  of  the  grant  is  to  maximize  the  benefits  of  the  infrastructure 
4. 
improvements 
for  ethnic  minority  women’s 
entrepreneurial activities in local tourism and awareness on health and hygiene issues. This will be 
achieved  through  (i)  capacity-building  training  on  issues  such  as  handicraft  fabrication,  food 
production,  marketing,  small  hostel  management,  cultural  heritage,  risks  in  community-based 
tourism,  and  communication;  (ii)  initiation  of  small  revolving  credit  funds  to  facilitate  small-
enterprise inception; (iii) construction of three shops in the project area which will have the capacity 
to store foodstuffs, handicrafts, and other commodities produced in the area and serve as meeting 
areas  for  women  to  participate  in  the  management  and  organization  of  marketing  of  cultural 
heritage to tourists; and (iv) three demonstration hygiene and sanitation projects in target villages 
focusing on women and childcare.

Success indicators will include (i) participation in workshops; (ii) creation of entrepreneurial 
activities  in  each  of  the  villages;  (iii)  participation  in  demonstration  projects,  and  (iv) creation  of 
training materials, which can be replicated in other communities. 
 
6. 
Implementation  Arrangements.  The  Kanas  Environmental  Protection  Construction  and 
Transportation  Bureau,  the  implementing  agency  for  the  Kanas  component  of  the  Xinjiang 
Municipal Infrastructure and Environmental Improvement Project, will carry out project coordination 
and procurement. It will be responsible for the construction of small infrastructure for the grant. In 
addition,  it  will  ensure  that  all  activities  are  harmonized  with  those  of  the  ethnic  minority 
development plan. 
 
7. 
The  Altay  Prefecture  branch  of  the  Women’s  Federation  has  already  begun  some  small-
scale training in the area for women on handicraft production. This proposal will further support that 
work and substantiate the content of the training and capacity building. The Women’s Federation 
will  work  with  the  Kanas  Environmental  Protection  Construction  and  Transportation  Bureau  and 
ensure implementation of, and reporting on, activities in each of the communities. 
 
A  consultant  will  be  engaged  to  coordinate  and  lead  the  training,  production  of  training 
8.

the Women’s Federation.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 
Country/Project  Title:  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC):  Xinjiang  Municipal  Infrastructure  and  Environmental

Department/

I.          POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The Xinjiang Municipal Infrastructure and Environmental Improvement Project will contribute to poverty reduction through 
removing  infrastructure  constraints,  addressing  environmental  concerns,  promoting  sustainable  economic  growth,  and 
supporting  institutional  reforms  in  three  of  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region’s  (Xinjiang’s)  border  cities  and  areas: 
Alashankou land port, Kanas scenic region, and Yining City. Xinjiang is PRC's largest region (17% of total area), with a 
relatively  small  population  (20  million),  62%  of  whom  belong  to  ethnic  minorities.  As  the  historic  Silk  Road  passes 
through  it,  Xinjiang  has  a  rich  history  and  culture  which  has  promoted  tourism  development.  Despite  these  assets,  it 
remains one of the poorest regions in the PRC, with 27 out of 22 cities and 68 counties classified as poor. In 2006, about 
8.4%  of  Xinjiang’s  urban  population  lived  on  incomes  below  the  official  poverty  line,  compared  with  the  4.0%  national 
average.  The  Project  is  in  line  with  the  PRC  poverty  reduction  strategy  for  development  of  the  western  region,  which 
seeks  to  decrease  the  gaps  created  by  eastern  PRC’s  rapid  economic  development  and  supports  the  government’s 
development  vision  of  xiaokang  (moderately  well-off)  articulated  in  the  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (11FYP,  2006–2010) 
aimed  at  maintaining  high  rates  of  growth,  but  channeling  it  towards  poverty  reduction  and  reducing  disparities.  The 
Project supports the PRC country partnership strategy priority areas of (i) strengthening inclusiveness through increasing 
investment  to  support  rural  development,  (ii)  promoting  regional  cooperation  and  integration,  and  (iii)  managing  the 
environment. The Project will do the following. 

(i)  Create  jobs  and  employment  opportunities. It is anticipated that 4,718 full-time jobs during the construction 
period and 7,549 follow-on multiplier effect jobs will be created. Of the construction jobs, 75% will be unskilled. 
The loan assurances specifically address employment of vulnerable groups, ethnic minorities, and women. 
Improve  living  standards.  Road  construction  will  facilitate  mobility,  access,  and  affordability  for  local 
populations to key basic services and destinations. Water and sanitation improvements will improve health and 
significantly reduce time burdens, particularly for women. Heating improvements will increase quality of life and 
reduce health issues related to home heating fuels. 

(ii) 

(iii)  Protect  the  environment. The environment management plan (EMP) outlines clear actions for environmental 

protection (land and water) during construction, and these are accounted for in the loan assurances. 

(iv)  Focus on ethnic minority areas. Xinjiang is predominantly an ethnic minority region. Yining City (with 93.0% of 
the total beneficiaries) and Kanas scenic region are both majority ethnic minority areas (75.0% of the population 
in Yining City and 99.5% in Kanas). 

(v)  Provide  skills  training.  The  Project  will  include  skills  training  (including  for  language,  construction,  livestock 
breeding,  agricultural  expansion,  and  local  tourism)  in  collaboration  with  other  stakeholders,  and  through  the 
resettlement plans and ethnic minority development plans (EMDPs). Vulnerable groups, ethnic minorities, and 
women are prioritized in the loan assurances. 

(vi)  Support gender inclusion. Loan assurances will ensure the participation of women throughout the Project. In 
addition, a grant for the Kanas Women’s Enterprise Development Project will ensure that women’s involvement 
in decision-making and development activities is brought into the mainstream. 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                    Targeting Classification:  Targeted Intervention–  

non-income Millennium Development Goals 

1. Key Issues 
The Project is classified as targeted intervention—Millennium Development Goals. It will benefit 471,418 people, 10% of 
whom are poor. Western China and Xinjiang have been identified in the PRC national development strategies as being 
geographically  disadvantaged  with  a  higher  incidence  of  poverty  than  other  regions,  calling  for  special  efforts  through 
prioritized allocation of resources. Yining City (the location of 93% of beneficiaries) has a high poverty rate with 15.7% of 
the  nonagricultural  population  entitled  to  the  minimum  standard  of  living  subsidy.  The  average  per  capita  income  in 
Yining of CNY311 is low compared to the Xinjiang urban average of CNY666. In Kanas poverty is high (20%), and 85% 
of households have a family income of less than CNY1,800 per month. According to the household survey, total mean 
family expenses equate to 91% of income. Nonincome poverty in Kanas is severe, and the cost of purchased goods is 
high due to the considerable transport costs. Alashankou has no minimum standard of living social welfare program. Its 
average per capita income is high, due in part to the large percentage (46%) of single people working there and to the 
higher than average wages offered to attract them to this remote location. The household survey indicates that the entire 
sampled  population  working  in  Alashankou  is  from  elsewhere—50%  from  Boertala  Mongolian  Autonomous  Prefecture 

 

 

  

Appendix 10 

43 

and 16% from elsewhere in Xinjiang. Incomes in Alashankou contribute to poverty alleviation at the points of origin of its 
workers. Yining and Kanas currently have high levels of unemployment (8% in Yining and 7% in Kanas), well above the 
under 4% target in the 11FYP. 

Poverty in the project area is largely rural and is most likely to affect those in the agricultural and livestock industries and 
to  be  experienced  by  ethnic  minorities.  The  following  three  factors  are  mutually  reinforcing:  ethnic  minorities  (except 
Uygurs) are more likely to live in rural (or peri-urban) areas, work in the primary sector, and have high dependency ratios. 
Poor people are not more likely to be undereducated, unemployed, or casual laborers. Benefits to poor people from the 
Project  will  be  increased  cash  incomes—through  employment  and  livelihood  expansion  in  sectors  such  as  cultural 
tourism—as  a  result  of  increased  prices  for  agricultural  products,  decreased  cost  of  inputs  from  improved  roads  and 
services, and reduced costs for medical expenses due to improved wastewater and public sanitation infrastructure. 

2. Design Features 
The  design  has  attempted  to  reduce  impacts  on  land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  Where  necessary,  the  resettlement 
plans  in  consultation  with  local  communities  have  outlined  mitigation  plans.  Project  assurances  call  for  employment  of 
local labor, especially vulnerable groups, ethnic minorities, and women. EMDPs outline strategies for mitigating adverse 
impacts  and  promoting  positive  benefits  such  as  employment,  skills  training,  language  training,  and  training  for 
contractors and workers on appropriate cultural understanding. Interpreters will facilitate the work of construction units. 

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Findings of Social Analysis 
The  Project  will  provide  infrastructure  for  25,307  household  water,  57,870  wastewater,  62,253  heating,  31,765 
telecommunications, and 9,510 electricity connections and 19,424 garbage collection receptacles. Most beneficiaries will 
be from ethnic minorities: 97% in Kanas, 82% in Yining, and 24% in Alashankou. 
 
Impacts on health and safety. Residents in Tiereketi village in Kanas currently get their water from the river. The water 
supply subcomponent will improve health and safety and save time in the village. All villages in Kanas will benefit from 
improved rubbish collection and disposal systems. Fifty five percent of households currently bury or burn their rubbish. 
Human waste is disposed of directly onto the ground and not every household has a toilet. Improvements to village water 
supply,  wastewater  disposal,  and  public  sanitation  (waste  collection  and  sanitary  toilets)  will  decrease  the  incidence  of 
disease. Over 50% of Kanas school children have missed at least one day of school in the last 12 months due to illness. 
Health  care  expenditure  is  high.  The  project  subcomponent  with  the  biggest  social  impact  in  Alashankou  is  garbage 
collection and treatment, with provision of a new sanitary landfill. Garbage is put into skips around the town but is blown 
around by the wind. Residents in the project areas of Yining have inadequate public utilities (water supply, wastewater, 
and  public  sanitation).  The  Yining  subproject  includes  public  toilets,  garbage  collection  stations,  dustbins,  garbage 
collection containers, garbage trucks, street cleaning trucks, and snow clearing trucks. Fifty nine percent of households 
bury  or  burn  their  rubbish;  the  incidence  of  respiratory  illness  is  very  high.  Expansion  of  the  public  heating  system  will 
improve respiratory health. 
 
Affordability.  Water  bills  are  low  and  represent  one  of  the  smallest  items  of  expenditure  measured  by  the  household 
survey. In Yining, if a poor family cannot afford to pay the water bill, generally the fee is waived; therefore tap water is 
universally affordable since a debt will never accumulate. Poor households consume about a third less fuel than average 
household consumption. Fuel cost is a significant item of expenditure for poor households (7.7% of income), compared 
with  just  3.8%  for  average  households.  The  residential  heating  charge  for  Yining  is  CNY17.5  per  month,  which  is 
significant for both average and poor households, and savings of CNY45.0 per month will accrue to average households 
and CNY25.0 to poor households. Garbage collection, wastewater, and water supply fees cost an average of CNY43.0 
per month. The savings to be gained by connecting to district heating will effectively pay for these public utilities for the 
average household. 
 
Impacts  on  employment. Approximately 4,718 full-time jobs will be created over the construction period and follow-on 
multiplier  effects  are  expected  to  create  7,549  full-time  jobs.  Currently  unemployed  persons  are  likely  to  fill  75%  of 
construction jobs (assumed to be unskilled jobs). This translates into CNY32.4 million of costs returned to the northwest 
Xinjiang economy. Operation and maintenance will create 572 additional full-time permanent jobs directly and 915 further 
jobs through multiplier effects, effectively directing about CNY4 million per year in wages into local economies. 
B. Consultation and Participation 
1. The technical assistance project utilized several participation processes for input from a range of stakeholders in the 
project  areas.  A  socioeconomic  survey  at  household  level  covered  608  households  and  information  relating  to  4,186 
people. Community meetings were held to discuss topics related to the technical assistance but not specifically covered 
in  the  socioeconomic  survey.  Key  informant  interviews  were  held  with  bureaus  and  nongovernment  organizations  to 
inform  the  project  design.  For  the  resettlement  plans,  separate  socioeconomic  surveys,  community  meetings,  opinion 
surveys,  and  specific  impact  studies  (500  people)  were  conducted.  Development  of  the  environmental  impact 
assessments  and  EMP  involved  two  rounds  of  public  consultations.  EMDPs  have  been  prepared  collaboratively  and 
extensively  discussed  with  communities.  The  resettlement  plans,  EMDPs,  and  EMP  set  out  detailed  ongoing  public 
participation plans.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 

Background 

A. 
 
1. 
Xinjiang Municipal Infrastructure and  Environmental Improvement Project consists of three 
components:  (i)  Yining  City  roads  and  municipal  services  (Yining  component);  (ii)  Kanas  scenic 
region  infrastructure  and  environmental  protection  (Kanas  component);  and  (iii) Alashankou  land 
port  municipal  infrastructure  and  environmental  protection  (Alashankou  component).  The  Yining 
component includes four main roads (13.23 kilometers [km]), reconstruction of 33 residential lanes 
(132.61 km) and environmental sanitation facilities such as public toilets, garbage collection units, 
and  associated  infrastructure.  The  Kanas  component,  which  seeks  to  address  the  infrastructure 
problems of the villages in Kanas, includes 24.28 km of roads, four parking lots, and water supply, 
wastewater  treatment,  and  solid  waste  management  systems.  The  Alashankou  component  will 
develop  infrastructure  facilities  for  the  land  port—including  a  landfill  and  waste  management 
system—to  encourage  expansion  of  cross-border  trade  and  protect  the  local  environment  from 
pollution. Based on the feasibility study report the Yining component will necessitate large amounts 
of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  compared  with  Kanas,  where  the  impacts  are  insignificant. 
Although the Alashankou component will occupy a large amount of state-owned land, the land is 
barren  and  no  people  will  be  affected.  A  full  resettlement  plan  has  been  prepared  for  the  Yining 
component  and  a  short  resettlement  plan  has  been  prepared  for  the  Kanas  component,  both  in 
compliance with Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). During 
project  implementation  the  resettlement  plans  will  be  updated  based  on  detailed  engineering 
design, will be disclosed to affected persons, and submitted to ADB for approval prior to award of 
civil works contracts. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
To  avoid  or  minimize  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  close  consultation  with  local 
officials, village committees, and affected persons have been undertaken during the resettlement 
plan preparation. The Project will affect seven villages of six townships and streets in Yining and 
Kanas.  Land  acquisition  and/or  house  demolition  will  directly  affect  2,021  persons  or 
354 households  (1,857  persons),  100  small  businesses,  and  an  enterprise  (164  persons).  In 
addition,  551.21  mu  (Chinese  unit  of  area,  15  mu  =  1  hectare)  of  state-owned  land  will  be 
permanently occupied; 575.11 mu of collective land will be acquired, of which 433.47 mu (75.4%) 
is  classified  as  cultivated  and/or  orchard  land;  53.1  mu  of  grassland  will  be  occupied  temporarily 
during  construction;  and  26,792.75  square  meters  (m2)  of  residential  housing  and  1,933.8  m2  of 
nonresidential buildings (1,855.8 m2  of shops and 78 m2  of enterprises) will be demolished. About 
100 small-business shops and a petrol station in Yining will be affected. Households (117) losing 
farmland  have  a  landholding  size  ranging  between  3  mu  and  7  mu  and  the  land  loss  ranges 
between 0.06 mu and 7 mu. The details are summarized in Table A11.

Policy and Legal Framework 

Resettlement and Rehabilitation 

C. 
 
3. 
The  resettlement  plans  have  been  prepared  in  compliance  with  the  Land  Administration 
Law of the People’s Republic of China (2004), relevant regulations of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous 
Region and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy. Based on consultation with local governments 
and  affected  persons  and  general  practices  in  the  project  area,  the  implementing  agencies  have 
adopted  a  set  of  resettlement  principles  and  an  entitlement  matrix  has  been  prepared  for  the 
Project.  Compensation  for  land  acquisition,  residential  housing,  and  nonresidential  buildings 
(shops  and  enterprises)  will  be  paid  to  all  users,  whether  titled  or  not.  For  land  acquisition, 
compensation  fees  include  land  compensation,  a  resettlement  subsidy,  and  compensation  for 
crops  and  trees.  The  land  compensation  will  be  paid  to  the  affected  villages  and/or  affected 
persons and the resettlement subsidy to the affected persons. The land acquisition compensation 
is  rated  at  the  land’s  average  annual  output  value.  For  business,  shop,  and  house  demolition, 
compensation will be paid to owners for rehabilitation of the affected persons. The compensation 
payments  will be in cash according to the appraised value of the land and fixed property assets. 
Compensation  for  crops,  trees,  other  facilities,  and  temporary  impacts  will  be  paid  directly  to 
affected  persons.  Income  losses  resulting  from  reduced  production  and/or  sales  and  wages 
caused by the Project will be assessed and compensated for in cash. 
 
D. 
 
4. 
To minimize the resettlement impacts to affected persons and restore their living standards, 
detailed  programs  of  restoration  and  relocation  have  been  arranged  in  each  resettlement  plan. 
People  can  choose  the  available  programs  according  to  their  requirements.  Based  on  the 
economic  characteristics  of  affected  villages,  different  schemes  for  income  restoration  will  be 
carried  out.  Since  the  resettlement  impacts  of  the  Kanas  component  are  very  slight,  the  affected 
villages  will  be  compensated  in  cash.  For  villages  seriously  affected  by  the  Yining  component, 
additional strategies and measures, including low-yield land improvement and livestock raising, will 
be  taken.  Assistance  measures—such  as  the  provision  of  employment  in  project  construction, 
provision  of  skills  training,  and  employment  information—will  be  provided  to  all  affected  persons 
(50% of whom are women). Through these measures, it is envisaged that all affected persons can 
maintain or acquire more stable incomes to restore and raise their living standards. For residential 
housing demolition, the affected households will receive compensation at replacement costs for the 
lost  structures  and  attachments  without  depreciation.  The  affected  households  can  rebuild  their 
houses  by  themselves  with  free  house  plots  provided  according  to  their  wishes.  Salvage  of  the 
structural  materials  will  be  allowed  and  a  relocation  subsidy  will  be  provided.  For  nonresidential 
buildings  and  structures  (small-business  shops  and  enterprises),  the  affected  owners  will  be 
compensated  with  cash  at  replacement  costs  for  the  lost  structures.  The  affected  shops  and 
enterprises  can  be  either  moved  back  and  rebuilt  on  the  existing  backyard  of  shops  along 
upgraded roads or built on free sites provided by the project management office (PMO), depending 
on  the  practicality  of  moving  back  and  their  wishes.  In  addition,  special  attention  will  be  paid  to 
vulnerable groups for their resettlement and rehabilitation; they will receive the following additional 
assistance: (i) the establishment of special supporting funds in each component, (ii) the provision 
of potential employment opportunities, and (iii) skills training. 
 
E. 
 
The cost estimate for land acquisition and resettlement of the Yining component and Kanas

defined in the resettlement plans, the payment and use of compensation funds will be carried out 
under  the  supervision  of  the  internal  monitoring  agencies,  with  regular  audit  review  and  regular

resettlement plans were posted on the ADB website on 17 December 2007. The PMO will set up

Implementation Arrangement and Schedule 

 
7. 
Xinjiang PMO will assume overall responsibility for the implementation of resettlement. Each 
city  and  area  PMO  under  it  coordinates  the  planning,  implementation,  financing,  and  reporting  of 
land acquisition and resettlement. The implementing agencies are the Yining Construction Bureau 
for the Yining component and the Kanas Environmental Protection Construction and Transportation 
Bureau for the Kanas component. The implementing agencies will take primary responsibility for the 
resettlement  consultation,  implementation,  and  timely  delivery  of  entitlements.  To  ensure  smooth 
implementation,  staff  in  charge  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  will  undertake  training  on 
resettlement  implementation  organized  by  the  Xinjiang  PMO.  The  resettlement  implementation 
schedule  for  the  Yining  component  and  Kanas  component  has  been  prepared  based  on  the 
preparation and construction timetable. No land acquisition or demolition will start until resettlement 
plans  are  updated  based  on  detailed  designs  and  approved  by  ADB.  It  is  anticipated  that  land 
acquisition and house demolition will start in March 2008 and be completed by the end of 2010. 
 
H. 
 
8. 
Internal  and  external  monitoring  of  resettlement  implementation  will  be  conducted.  Each 
PMO will carry out internal supervision and monitoring to ensure compliance with the provisions of 
the  resettlement  plan.  Xinjiang  PMO  and  the  city  and  area  PMOs  will  engage  an  independent 
agency  for  semi-annual  monitoring  and  annual  evaluation  for  the  Yining  component  and  annual 
monitoring  and  evaluation  for  the  Kanas  component  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  until  2 
years  after  the  completion  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  The  independent  agency  will 
monitor  and  evaluate  the  progress  of  resettlement  implementation,  payment,  and  dispute 
resolution.  It  will  identify  the  impacts  for  affected  persons  on  (i)  whether  they  have  received  the 
approved compensation and entitlements on time, and (ii) whether their living standard and income 
level  have  been  restored  to  pre-project  status.  A  baseline  survey  will  be  carried  out  before  land 
acquisition and house demolition starts. External monitoring reports will be forwarded directly to the 
PMO and ADB.

SUMMARY ETHNIC MINORITY DEVELOPMENT PLAN 

Introduction 

Project Descriptions 

Socioeconomic Profiles 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The  Yining  City  and  Kanas  scenic  region  ethnic  minority  development  plans  (EMDPs) 
ensure that ethnic minorities will benefit equitably from the Project and that any negative impacts 
will  be  reduced  or  mitigated.  Provisions  to  improve  the  economic  conditions  of  ethnic  minorities 
have been integrated into the project design and project assurances. Special mitigation measures 
are included in the resettlement plans to ensure that ethnic minority communities affected by land 
acquisition  benefit  from  the  Project.  Government  policies  and  programs  for  ethnic  minority 
development further protect and enhance project benefits. The EMDPs are based on relevant laws 
and  regulations  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s 
(ADB’s) Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The Yining City roads and municipal services component includes (i) road construction and 
associated  infrastructure,  and  (ii)  environmental  sanitation  facilities.  The  Kanas  scenic  region 
infrastructure and environmental protection component includes (i) road reconstruction and parking 
lots, (ii) water supply and wastewater treatment facility construction, (iii) provision of infrastructure 
for  sanitation  and  solid  waste  treatment  (toilets,  solid  waste  collection  trucks  and  depots,  and  a 
solid waste landfill), and (iv) revegetation of the environment and plants destroyed or damaged as 
a result of past road construction. 
 
C. 
 
As  PRC’s  largest  autonomous  region  or  province,  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region 
3. 
(Xinjiang)  is  a  low-income  region  with  a  small  population  (20  million),  made  up  of  62%  ethnic 
minorities, the largest of which are the Uygur. Located on the PRC’s western border, Yining City is 
the capital of the Yili Kazak Autonomous Prefecture. Previously part of the northern pass of the Silk 
Road,  today  the  prefecture  has  become  an  important  trading  port  and  international  connection 
point  with  more  than  2,000  kilometers  of  international  border  and  eight  land  ports.  Kanas  scenic 
region  is  close  to  the  northwest  border  of  the  PRC.  It  is  a  premier  tourism  site  and  a  priority 
development area for Xinjiang and the PRC’s western region development strategy. Tourism has 
rapidly developed with an average yearly increase of almost 64% since 1997, resulting in 760,000 
tourist trips in 2006, generating a total of CNY0.46 billion in tourism revenue. 
 
4. 
In  2006,  the  population  of  Yining  City  was  471,418,  and  62%  of  these  people  were 
nonagricultural.  Thirty  two  ethnic  minority  groups—including  Uygur,  Kazak,  Hui,  Russian, 
Mongolian,  Xibo,  Kirgiz,  Tajik,  and  Tatar—living  primarily  in  mixed  communities  account  for  two 
thirds of Yining’s population. The poverty rate is high, with 15.7% of the nonagricultural population 
entitled  to  the  minimum  standard  of  living  subsidy.  The  average  per  capita  income  in  Yining  of 
CNY311 is low compared to the Xinjiang urban average of CNY666.  
 
5. 
The  population  of  the  four  main  project  affected  villages  of  Kanas,  Tiereketi,  Hemu,  and 
Baihaba1 is  approximately  3,629  and  is  99.5%  ethnic  minority—Kazak  (49.5%),  Mongolian  Tuwa 
(48.4%), and Hui (1.7%). The people are pastoralists, living in villages for the winter and tents on 
remote grazing lands in the summer. Poverty is high (20%), and 85% of households have a family 
income  of  less  than  CNY1,800  per  month.  According  to  the  household  survey,  total  mean  family 
expenses per month equate to 91% of income. Small-scale tourism is increasingly being entered 
into,  but  important  barriers—such  as  poor  infrastructure  and  language  skills—have  limited  the 
opportunities to date. Access to improved water supply and sanitation is low to nonexistent.

Project Benefits and Impacts 

D. 
 
6. 
The EMDPs ensure that (i) ethnic minority people are given opportunities to participate in all 
stages and receive the benefits of the Project, and (ii) the strategies developed to mitigate against 
negative  impacts  are  sensitive  to  the  culture  of  affected  minority  groups.  Project  assurances 
address prioritization of ethnic minorities and vulnerable groups for employment opportunities. The 
skills and language training will help ensure sustainability of incomes and livelihoods. 
 
7. 
Yining City. The poverty and social assessment indicates that the overall positive impacts 
of  the  Project  (improved  mobility  and  access,  sanitation,  and  environmental  protection)  on  ethnic 
minorities  will  be  the  same  as  on  the  Han  population.  The  Project  involves  resettlement  and 
relocation due to demolition of houses and shops. Of the 255 affected person households, 70% are 
ethnic minorities. The resettlement plan and the environmental management plan outline strategies 
for mitigation of negative impacts that will be applicable to both ethnic minorities and Han people. 
In cooperation with the Civil Affairs Department, the resettlement plan also outlines special funds 
which  have  been  established  to  provide  additional  aid,  including  subsidies  and  medical  care  for 
vulnerable  and  ethnic  minority  groups.  The  project  management  office  has  agreed  to  the 
assurances  obliging  contractors  to  employ  local  labor,  and  workers  from  ethnic  minorities  will  be 
particularly targeted. Skills training in construction, tourism, and livestock and language training will 
be  provided  in  coordination  with  other  government  and  local  stakeholders.  Attention  to  ethnic 
minority cultural issues will be addressed through awareness building with workers and prohibitions 
on  construction  near  religious  sites  on  particular  days.  HIV/AIDS  information  and  education 
activities  will  be  supported  by  the  Project  and  the  Yining  Center  for  Disease  Control.  The 
expansion  of  bus  and  taxi  services  will  pay  attention  to  ensuring  that  public  transportation  is 
available for the new relocation sites and improved roads (predominantly ethnic minority areas). 
 
Kanas. The poverty and social assessment indicates that ethnic minorities will be the major 
8. 
beneficiaries of improvements to the water supply and sanitation infrastructure, and that women’s 
work  in  domestic  and  community  cleaning,  and  care  of  children,  the  sick,  and  elderly,  will  be 
reduced.  The  village  roads  will  allow  tourists  access  to  the  area  and  facilitate  participation  of 
villagers in tourism activities which showcase their culture. Provision of carparks and public toilets 
will ensure that tourists do not damage the environment, reducing the quality of life and resource 
base  for  the  residents.  Revegetation  of  roadside  areas  (damaged  during  the  road  project  which 
provided  access  to  Buerjin  County)  and  further  greening  work  will  ensure  the  Project  has 
sustainable environmental benefits and does not contribute to the erosion of grasslands. More than 
1,310 construction jobs and 245 permanent operations-period jobs will be created in an area with 
high  (almost  7%)  unemployment.  Project  assurances  address  local  employment  and  HIV/AIDS 
awareness  issues.  Impacts  are  expected  to  be  gender  neutral,  with  men  benefiting  more  from 
temporary job creation and women from reduced domestic and care work, opportunities for income 
generation from tourism growth, and project-related business initiatives. Ongoing improvements to 
grassland management and stock breeding, to which the Project will contribute, will improve family 
incomes. A Gender and Development Fund grant for the Kanas Women’s Enterprise Development 
Project will strengthen project outcomes for local women by building capacity at the local level for 
management  and  marketing  of  local  tourism  and  integrating  women’s  traditional  knowledge  on 
handicrafts and local foods for livelihood and tourism development. It also supports demonstration 
projects  in  health  and  hygiene  to  maximize  the  impacts  of  improved  water  and  sanitation 
infrastructure. 
 
E. 
 
9. 
During  preparation,  affected  persons  and  ethnic  minority  populations  living  in  Yining  City 
and  Kanas  scenic  region  were  extensively  consulted  about  the  likely  impacts  of  the  Project  and 
participated  in  outlining  actions  to  improve  positive  outcomes.  Other  stakeholders  consulted 
include  (i)  heads  of  affected  person  households,  (ii)  village  heads  and  villagers’  representatives, 
(iii)  local  government  agencies  and  departments,  and  (iv)  women  and  vulnerable  groups.  From

Implementation and Institutional Arrangements 

June  to  August  2007,  consultative  meetings  were  held  in  Yining,  Kanas,  Buerjin,  and  Urumqi  to 
discuss and finalize the EMDPs. The EMDPs were endorsed and disclosed to the targeted villages, 
townships,  and  subdistricts  in  mid-October  2007,  and  were  posted  on  the  ADB  website  on  12 
December 2007. The participation and disclosure plan will use notices and meetings to deal with all 
aspects  of  the  Project,  such  as  notification  of  employment  and  training  opportunities,  land 
acquisition  details,  EMDP  actions,  and  general  information  and  feedback  sessions.  During  the 
project implementation period, the project management offices will encourage affected persons to 
participate  in  the  extra  resettlement  activities  such  as  skills  training.  Ethnic  minorities  will 
participate  in  the  formulation  of  compensation  standards  and  relocation  plans.  To  resolve  any 
grievances and ensure smooth construction and project implementation, a clear, transparent, and 
efficient  complaint  and  appeal  channel  with  redress  mechanisms  has  been  outlined.  This  will  be 
the same for grievances arising from both resettlement plan and EMDP implementation. Monitoring 
indicators related to participation and feedback have been incorporated into the plan. 
 
F. 
 
10. 
For the Yining component, the Yining municipal government and executing agency will be 
responsible  for  implementing  the  EMDP.  The  Ethnic  Affairs  Bureau  will  provide  support  to 
coordinate,  advise,  and  monitor  implementation  progress.  Implementation  arrangements  for  the 
EMDPs  have  been  integrated  into  project  management,  or  are  part  of  ongoing  government 
programs. Other agencies include the Center for Disease Control, Civil Affairs Bureau, Labor and 
Social Security Bureau, and All China Women’s Federation. The Yining Ethnic Affairs Bureau will 
provide  oversight  and  review  of  external  monitoring  and  evaluation  reports,  and  provide 
recommendations.  Township  governments  and  subdistrict  offices  will  assign  staff 
for 
implementation and coordination. The executing agency will have a member responsible for EMDP 
implementation.  For  the  Kanas  component,  the  Kanas  scenic  region  management  committee 
(KSRMC)  of  Altay  Prefecture  will  be  the  implementing  agency  for  the  Project.  The  KSRMC  will 
implement the EMDP, supported by the Civil Administration Bureau, Ethnic Affairs Administration 
Commission, and Women’s Federation of Altay Prefecture. Implementing partners include the local 
townships,  local  governments,  village  committees  and  project  contractors.  Local  government 
staffing, related costs, and planned related projects are covered by their administrative budgets. 
 
G. 
 
11. 
The EMDP activities will not require a separate budget. The actions are included either as 
part of the project budgets or as part of local government development budgets. Local government 
agencies will collaborate with the executing agency, Yining City government and the KSRMC; the 
local government budgets cover their staffing and related costs. Project actions are costed under 
the  resettlement  plans  and  project  contracts.  The  Gender  and  Development  Fund  will  provide 
$150,000 for the Kanas Women’s Enterprise Development Project. 
 
H. 
 
12. 
Regular  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  EMDPs  will  ensure  the  plans  are  implemented 
properly. Objectives of the monitoring and evaluation plans with respect to ethnic minorities will be 
(i) to collect data and information to identify project impacts based on the development monitoring 
framework in the poverty and social assessment and the monitoring frameworks for resettlement, 
including qualitative information to describe social or poverty changes on ethnic minorities and their 
communities;  and  (ii)  to  ensure  that  appropriate  approaches  have  been  adopted  and  the  goals 
have  been  achieved.  Yining  City  government  and  the  KSRMC  will  undertake  internal  monitoring. 
Independent  organizations  will  be  hired  for  each  area  in  conjunction  with  the  resettlement  plan 
external  monitoring  agency  to  provide  independent  advice  on  progress,  impacts,  and  outcomes. 
Terms of reference for external monitoring are appended to the EMDPs. The Yining component is 
scheduled  to  commence  in  2008  and  finish  in  2012.  The  Kanas  component  is  scheduled  to 
commence in 2008 and finish in 2012.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 

Introduction 

A. 
 
1. 
Financial  analysis  has  been  prepared  in  accordance  with  Asian  Development  Bank’s 
(ADB’s)  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of  Projects  (2005).  An  assessment  of  financial 
performance  has  been  completed  for  the  Yining  municipal  government,  Boertala  Mongolian 
Autonomous  Prefecture  (BMAP)  government,  and  Altay  Prefecture  government.  The  financial 
analysis  has  been  undertaken  for  the  revenue  generating  subcomponents  such  as  water  supply, 
wastewater treatment, and heating supply. A financial sustainability analysis has been undertaken 
for the nonrevenue-generating subcomponents such as the roads, vegetation recovery, solid waste 
treatment, and protective forests. 
 
B. 
 

Revenue Generating Subcomponents 

Objective and Approach 

1. 
 
The financial analysis examines (and identifies required) income streams over a projected 
2. 
period  and  assesses  these  against  the  costs  related  to  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M), 
including debt servicing. This is undertaken on a present value basis and measured by a financial 
internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR).  Assumptions  have  been  made  for  the  applicable  subcomponent’s 
operations, leading to a with-project and without-project analysis and stream of incremental costs 
and revenues over a 25-year period, including a 5-year implementation period. All analyses are in 
real  terms  using  mid-2007  prices.  The  base-case  financial  model  FIRR  is  compared  with  the 
subcomponent’s weighted average cost of capital (WACC) to determine financial sustainability. A 
sensitivity  analysis  further  assesses  the  impact  of  changes  in  cost  and  revenue  assumptions  on 
the  base-case  FIRR.  This  therefore  allows  a  conclusion  on  the  financial  sustainability  of  the 
project-created  assets  to  be  made  as  well  as  identification  of  necessary  measures  for 
sustainability. 
 

Weighted Average Cost of Capital 

2. 
 
3. 
The WACC has been calculated in real terms for each subcomponent. Funding sources for 
the water supply, wastewater, and heating supply infrastructure subcomponents are the ADB loan 
and  counterpart  funds  from  the  Yining  municipal  government,  BMAP  government,  and  Altay 
Prefecture government. The Ministry of Finance will relend the ADB loan to the BMAP government 
and  Altay  Prefecture  government  at  6.2%  (London  interbank  offered  rate  of  5.6%  and  service 
charge of 0.6%). The local inflation rate is 3% per annum and international inflation rate is 2%. The 
WACC has been determined to be 3.2% for the water supply and wastewater subcomponents and 
3.1% for the heating subcomponent for Alashankou land port. 
 

3. 

Alashankou Land Port Existing and Projected Tariffs for the Financial Internal 
Rate of Return Analysis 

 
4. 
The Project—which is in line with Government policy to achieve phased full cost recovery in 
water, wastewater, and heating—will recover the O&M costs of the water supply, wastewater, and 
heating  supply,  depreciation,  and  loan  repayments  from  user  charges.  The  existing  tariff  of 
CNY1.56 per cubic meter (m3) for the water supply, CNY1.50 per m3 for wastewater, and CNY34 
per household per month for heating will be increased gradually until full cost recovery has been 
achieved. 1  This  allows  for  affordable  tariffs  and  gives  sufficient  revenue  to  the  prefecture 
government  to  operate  the  Project’s  facilities  and  finance  replacement  of  short-lived  assets.  The 
wastewater tariffs will be levied as an amount for each m3 of water consumed. The wastewater fee 
will be included on water supply bills as a separate additional item. The water supply, wastewater, 

                                                 
1   Following Ministry of Construction guidance announced by the vice minister on 22 August 2006. 

 Appendix 13 

53 

 

 

and  heating  tariffs  will  be  increased  annually  during  the  implementation  period  so  that  subsidies 
will be eliminated. In addition, the service coverage and tariff collection efficiency will be gradually 
improved to increase revenues to the service providers. Charges are set higher for commercial and 
industrial  consumers  to  help  ensure  affordability  for  domestic  users,  especially  for  low-income 
households. 
 
5. 
The  detailed  financial  projections  of  Alashankou  land  port  assume  that  the  BMAP 
government will be able to gradually increase tariffs after project completion until full cost-recovery 
has  been  achieved.  BMAP  shall  undertake  operational  improvements—such  as  reduction  of  the 
systems  losses  and  unaccounted-for  water—to  increase  water  revenue,  reduce  accounts 
receivable, and undertake individual connections and metering prior to project completion. These 
measures  must  be  initiated  prior  to  project  completion  to  ensure  financial  sustainability  of 
operations. The Project addresses these operational improvements through loan assurances. The 
detailed projections for the heating supply assume that additional generation capacity will be built 
and will be available by 2015. Heating revenues from 2012 have been based on increased tariffs 
and,  after  construction  of  the  additional  capacity,  revenues  have  been  derived  from  increased 
service  coverage  and  tariffs.  The  cost  of  construction  of  the  additional  capacity  has  been 
considered in the financial analysis. 
 
6. 
It  is  anticipated  that  the  tariffs  will  be  increased  gradually  to  full  cost-recovery  levels  for 
O&M  and  depreciation.  By  2009,  when  loan  repayment  begins,  tariffs  must  cover  interest 
repayments. After 2014, tariffs should cover principal repayments to ensure that they can finance 
operations  and  debt  repayment.  This  is  reasonable  since  the  Project  will  improve  (i)  service 
delivery, (ii) efficiency gains, (iii) tariff restructuring and reforms, and (iv) education and awareness 
of  tariff  increases.  Table  A13.1  shows  the  projected  cost-recovery  levels  and  projected  tariffs 
(which  are  based  on  affordability)  used  in  the  financial  analysis.  The  Government  agrees  to  the 
gradual tariff increase.

Financial Internal Rate of Return 

 
9. 
Base-case  FIRRs  and  financial  performance  indicators  for  water  supply,  wastewater,  and 
heating supply subcomponents in Alashankou land port are provided in Table A13.3. The after-tax 
FIRR  for  the  base-case  scenario  for  the  water  supply  subcomponent  is  estimated  at  6.9%,  for 
wastewater  5.8%,  and  for  heating  supply  11.2%,  and  varies  between  4.2%  and  7.9%  for  the 
various  sensitivity  cases.  The  results  compare  favorably  to  the  WACC  of  3.2%  for  both  water 
supply  and  wastewater  subcomponents  and  3.1%  for  the  heating  supply,  which  assume  gradual 
tariff  increases  at  the  onset  of  project  implementation.  The  recommended  tariff  increases  are 
required to cover the full cost of O&M, depreciation, interest, and principal during loan repayment. 
Periodic tariff reviews and approval of appropriate tariff reforms by the prefecture government will 
be  required  to  reduce  the  risk  of  poor  financial  performance  or  of  unexpected  changes  in  tariff 
income. The Project addresses tariff restructuring and review in loan assurances. 
 
The  financial  analysis  assumes  that  the  BMAP  government  will  be  able  to  charge  the 
10. 
gradual  increase  in  tariffs  until  full  cost-recovery  has  been  achieved  and  undertake  operational 
improvements—such as reduction of the systems losses and unaccounted-for water—to increase 
water  revenue,  reduce  accounts  receivable,  and  undertake  individual  connections  and  metering 
prior to project completion. These measures must be initiated prior to project completion to ensure 
financial sustainability of operations.

the Yining municipal government annual capital expenditure budget, 1% of the BMAP government 
annual  capital  expenditure  budget  and  3%  of  the  Altay  Prefecture  government  annual  capital 
expenditure budget. 
 
16. 
Adequate  maintenance  is  crucial  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  the  road  subcomponents 
under the Project where the local governments are responsible. A reliable funding mechanism for 
maintenance  and  rehabilitation  of  roads  must  be  designed.  The  establishment  of  a  road  fund 
should be considered but it should encompass the whole road network of Yining, Alashankou, and 
Kanas, not only the project roads. The establishment of such a fund will require legislation in order 
to  achieve  the  goals.  Possible  sources  for  the  road  fund  could  be  (i)  a  fuel  levy,  (ii)  vehicle 
registration and license fees, and (iii) road tolls. Though the identified annual funds (Table A13.5) 
were  assured  to  be  available  to  the  Project,  there  are  still  other  competing  demands  for 
government  funds;  thus  each  prefecture  government  should  consider generating  additional  funds 
through direct maintenance charges and adopting measures to increase revenues. 
 
E. 
 
17. 
the  executing  agency  (the  Xinjiang  Uygur 
Autonomous Region government) and the implementing agencies has been undertaken using the 
financial management questionnaire provided by ADB. It determines the accounting and financial 
capacity needs during project implementation and operations after project completion. The Xinjiang 
Uygur  Autonomous  Region  government  has  a  sound  financial  management  system  in  place  and 
has  previous  experience  in  managing  foreign-assisted  projects,  confirming  that  their  financial 
management practices are fully adequate for implementation of the Project. For the implementing 
agencies, each water, sanitation, and heating utility will be assisted to establish a sound financial 
management system at the beginning of project implementation. Each utility will keep accounts in 
accordance with commercial accounting principles and be subject to an independent external audit 
by a suitably qualified firm of commercial auditors. Accounting will be in accordance with relevant 
People’s  Republic  of  China  accounting  standards,  which  are  largely  in  accordance  with 
international norms. A capacity-building component to strengthen financial management has been 
included in the Project. 
 
18. 
The  staff  will  need  training  in  project  management  and  relevant  ADB  procedures  during 
implementation of the Project. With the help of international and national consultants, capacity will 
be  strengthened  in  (i)  efficient  operations  of  the  water  supply,  wastewater,  and  heating  facilities; 
(ii) functional  areas  covering  administration,  finance,  accounting,  and  business  planning;  and 
(iii) management information systems and cost management and control.

Appendix 14 

57 

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 

Introduction 

Analysis of the Overall Project 

A. 
 
1. 
The  economic  analysis  covers  three  components  and  13  subcomponents.  For  the  overall 
Project,  the  analysis  covers  (i)  economic  rationale  for  public  intervention,  (ii)  the  goals  of  the 
investment  plan,  and  (iii)  the  design  of  the  plan.  The  economic  analysis  also  evaluates  the 
subcomponents  relative  to  least-cost  analysis  criteria  and  standard  benefit–cost  analysis. 
Economic  analysis  has  been  conducted  in  accordance  with  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB) 
Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects  (1997)  and  Economic  Analysis  Retrospective 
2005: Strengthening Quality-at-Entry of ADB’s Operations (2006). The detailed economic analysis 
and least-cost analysis are in Supplementary Appendix N. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
Rationale for Public Intervention. The primary motivation for the Project results from the 
increasing concern over the effects of population growth and economic growth on the inadequacy 
of  public  services  in  the  towns  and  cities  of  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region  (Xinjiang). 
Continuing urbanization has resulted in increasing water shortages as well as major deficiencies in 
urban  road  networks  and  services.  Furthermore,  urban  areas  face  environmental  threats  from 
pollution of surface and subsurface waters from untreated wastewater and garbage. In 2005, the 
urban population in Xinjiang accounted for 37% of the total population. This is expected to increase 
to 42% by 2010 and 47% by 2015. 
 
3. 
The strategic location of Xinjiang as a major transport corridor and as the gateway between 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and  the  Central  Asian  countries1 is  expected  to  spur  economic 
development  and  contribute  to  tourism  development.  The  region  is  also  rich  in  natural  resources 
including oil, metals, and minerals, which provide a sound basis for economic development. With 
the  expected  rise  in  trade  and  tourism  brought  about  by  cooperation  activities  under  the  Central 
Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  Program,  development  of  necessary  infrastructure  support 
facilities is critical to sustained economic growth and development. 
 
4. 
The Project involves government intervention at several different levels. The Xinjiang Uygur 
Autonomous  Region  government  is  promoting  development  in  the  cities  and  towns  in  a  more 
coordinated and cost-effective manner by bringing about more sustainable investments in physical 
and environmental protection infrastructure that aims to improve the quality of life. Involvement of 
the  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region  government  is  justified  since  the  development  program 
spans  several  regions  and  cities.  The  municipal  governments  are  coordinating  and  implementing 
the  elements  of  the  master  plans  and  making  individual  investments  in  the  roads,  water  supply, 
sanitation,  and  wastewater  works  and  will  be  involved  in  owning  and  managing  some  of  the 
completed facilities. 
 
Goals and Design of the Project. The Project is a direct response to Xinjiang’s Eleventh 
5. 
Five-Year  Plan  (11FYP)  to  promote  sustainable  economic  development,  particularly  in  its  border 
cities  and  areas,  via  construction  and  upgrading  of  the  infrastructure  in  major  border  ports,  while 
protecting  the  environment.  The  11FYP  recognizes  that  achievement  of  these  goals  will  require 
improvement  of  the  basic  municipal  services  and  environmental  quality  in  these  areas.  All 
subcomponents  in  the  proposed  Project  are  integral  components  in  the  11FYP.  Municipal 
governments are required to make investments in water supply, wastewater, ecological upgrading 
and solid waste management. The city and area government master plans are reasonably sound 
and are integrated with the overall planning process. 
 

                                                 
1   The  Second  Eurasia  Continental  Bridge  railway  line  connects  Europe  to  East  Asia  through  the  Xinjiang  Uygur 

Autonomous Region. 

 

 58 

Appendix 14 

Demand Analysis 

Evaluation of Individual Components 

C. 
 
6. 
Traffic surveys have been carried out under the feasibility study reports. Traffic forecast has 
been  determined  based  on  socioeconomic  trends  that  have  taken  into  account  changes  in 
variables such as gross domestic product (GDP), population, and vehicle ownership. The forecast 
GDP  growth  rates  have been  applied  to  the calibrated  base-year  matrices  to  produce  passenger 
and  freight  vehicle  flows.  Traffic  projections  have  also  taken  into  account  potential  generated 
traffic.  It  is  concluded  from  a  review  of  the  demand  forecast  for  the  water  supply,  solid  waste 
management,  and  wastewater  and  heating  supply  carried  out  by  the  feasibility  study  report 
consultants  that  the  risk  associated  with  demand  forecast  in  the  economic  analysis  would  be 
minimal. This is because the Project will provide supply to meet existing demand or only a fraction 
of the total demand in the project cities and areas. 
 
D. 
 
7. 
The least-cost analysis ensures that each subcomponent is optimally designed to meet the 
goals  of  the  Project,  and  does  not  involve  unnecessary  extra  costs.  The  least-cost  analysis  has 
covered  all  feasible  options  for  a  given  subcomponent,  including  variations  in  technology  and 
location. Since there is no unique least-cost plan to achieve the development targets, any plan that 
minimizes  cost  is  acceptable  in  principle.  For  instance,  water  improvements  may  be  achieved  at 
least  cost  through  a  centralized  water  supply,  which  needs  to  be  connected  to  the  main  water 
system. To vastly reduce unaccounted-for water and eliminate subsidies over time, all customers in 
each of the subcomponents will have metered connections. The estimated average economic cost 
of  each  of  the  water  supply  and  wastewater  treatment  subcomponents  has  been  analyzed.  The 
present  value  of  economic  cost  approach  has  been  adopted  for  the  roads,  ecological  upgrading, 
heating supply, and solid waste management subcomponents. Detailed calculation and discussion 
of the cost-effectiveness analysis is presented in Supplementary Appendix N. 
 
8. 
In addition to being part of the 11FYP, each subcomponent is economically justified on its 
own. Economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) have been estimated for roads, water supply, solid 
waste management, and heating supply subcomponents. The EIRRs are compared with economic 
opportunity  cost  of  capital  (EOCC),  which  is  assumed  to  be  12%.  Major  benefits  that  have  been 
quantified for each subcomponent include the following. 
 

(i)  Roads.  (a)  Savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs  resulting  from  reduced  travel  distance  and 
improved  road  conditions,  (b)  savings  resulting  from  fewer  accidents,  (c)  reduced 
maintenance  costs,  (d)  savings  in  the  value  of  passengers’  time,  (e)  generated  traffic 
resulting  from  reduced  transportation  costs,  and  (f)  value  of  additional  tourism  in  Kanas 
scenic region that is attributable to the subcomponent. 

(ii)  Water supply. Health benefits are assumed as captured by the households’ willingness to 

pay.2 

(iii) Environmental  sanitation.  (a)  Cost  of  illness  savings  (savings  in  medical  expenses) 
brought  about  by  the  prevention  of  an  increase  in  the  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases 
arising from contamination of water; and (b) prevention of the associated increase in time 
lost from work leading to a loss of income, thus, less time lost to illness and also less time 
spent for the care of sick family members. 

(iv) Heating  supply. (a) User cost savings, (b) household time savings for not refueling home 
furnaces  and  handling  of  coal,  and  (c)  local  environmental  benefits  from  improved  air 
quality  as  a  result  of  reduction  in  open  burning  of  coal  and  reduced  dust  associated  with 
handling and storage of coal. Evaluation follows the benefit transfer method. 

                                                 
2   Health benefits have been  estimated but not considered in  the economic internal rate  of  return calculations of  water 
supply subcomponents since they are an assumed part of willingness to pay. Health impact relates to deficiencies in 
solid waste management facilities as well as other environmental factors. 

 

  

Appendix 14 

59 

9. 
Water  supply  benefits  are  estimated  using  a  willingness-to-pay  approach.  Water  supply 
customers were asked to state their willingness to pay for service improvements and their revealed 
willingness-to-pay  is  used  to  measure  benefits  to  customers.  The  willingness-to-pay  survey  was 
conducted on a total of 100 households in Alashankou land port, which represents 10% of the total 
household  population  in  the  district.  Households’  willingness-to-pay  gathered  from  the  results  of 
the  household  survey  has  been  analyzed  using  a  multivariate  regression  model.  The  mean 
willingness-to-pay  multiplied  by  the  total  number  of  households  served  by  the  water  supply 
subcomponent  provides  the  gross  benefit  of  the  Project.  The  detailed  estimation  of  the  mean 
willingness-to-pay is in Supplementary Appendix N. 
 
10. 
The economic analysis has been conducted over 25 years, including project construction in 
2008  and  completion  in  2013.  Economic  benefits  and  costs  are  denominated  in  domestic  price 
numeraire  at  constant  mid-2007  prices.  Foreign  currency  costs  have  been  converted  into  local 
currency  costs  using  an  exchange  rate  of  CNY7.45  per  $1  and  adjusted  based  on  purchasing 
power  parity  assumption.  Project  tradable  components  have  been  adjusted  to  economic  prices 
using  a  shadow  exchange  rate  factor  of  1.013  and  nontradable  components  valued  at  domestic 
market  prices.  Project  costs  and  benefits  have  been  estimated  on  a  without-project  and  with-
project  basis.  Transfer  payments  have  been  excluded.  Standard  sensitivity  tests,  and  additional 
tests  for  a  1-year  implementation  delay  and  20%  increase  in  operation  and  maintenance  costs, 
have been conducted. 
 
11. 
The  economic  costs  include  (i)  the  capital  cost,  including  physical  contingencies,  land 
acquisition,  resettlement,  and  environmental  mitigation  costs;  and  (ii)  the  cost  of  operation  and 
maintenance,  including  the  cost  of  replacement  of  depreciated  equipment.  The  land  acquisition 
and  resettlement  costs  have  been  based  on  their  opportunity  costs,  i.e.,  the  agricultural  output 
forgone and the re-siting of displaced economic activities.3 Residual values have been treated as 
negative costs at the end of the project life. 
 
12. 
Yining City Infrastructure and Municipal Services Component. Table A14.1 shows the 
results of the base cases and sensitivity tests. EIRRs are higher than the EOCC of 12%, indicating 
that the roads (including institutional development) are economically justified.
